commit_message:
Fix ACL for microversion-parse

microversion-parse was recently[1] adopted by oslo, and as such should
leverage the release management team and the releases repo to produce
releases. This removes ACL allowing to directly push releases.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/68d2cea52f3d4d35ce0aefff4d0a01f51cb39d7a

Change-Id: I50063c7bf8a34e9566986ff75cfef7c83f73187b

commit_message:
Deprecate openstack-python-jobs templates

OpenStack is moving to release specific templates, explain that the
openstack-python-jobs templates are only to be used for older stable
branches (train and older).

Change-Id: I69c30ce501b53edf711b42c949849353e27e4f9d

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-03 13:06:24.000000000', 'message': 'Add octavia-ovn-provider driver project

This patch adds new project under Octavia group -
Octavia OVN Provider driver, to interact Octavia
with OVN LoadBalancer.

A few days ago Neutron community decided to merge
Networking-ovn tree with Neutron tree [0]. Nowadays
Octavia OVN provider driver is placed in networking-ovn
repository and it uses Octavia and Octavia-lib. To not
force Neutron to rely on Octavia we should export the driver
to dedicated repository.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658414/

Change-Id: Id4a5beb324e2fa0d119df532c24fc28503155d1b

commit_message:
Add ovn-octavia-provider driver project

This patch adds a new project under the Neutron group -
OVN Octavia Provider driver, for Neutron's
interaction with the OVN LoadBalancer for Octavia.

A few days ago the Neutron community decided to merge
Networking-ovn tree with the Neutron tree [0]. Nowadays,
the OVN Octavia provider driver is placed in networking-ovn
repository and it uses Octavia and Octavia-lib. To not
force Neutron to rely on Octavia we should export the driver
to a dedicated repository.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658414/

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697095/
Change-Id: Id4a5beb324e2fa0d119df532c24fc28503155d1b

This seems like a fine way to ease into things, folks can get non-voting arm64 jobs on every change by placing them in this pipeline, or use the normal experimental pipeline for on-demand builds. This also doesn't preclude projects using arm64 jobs (sparingly for now) in the gate pipeline if they want to rely on them to prevent merging architecture-specific bugs."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-11 23:14:04.000000000', 'message': "zuul: arm64 pipeline

ARM64 testing is of interest to a number of projects.  For example:

 https://review.opendev.org/662456 : kolla
 https://review.opendev.org/676111 : diskimage-builder
 https://review.opendev.org/690798 : system-config (mirror tests)

However, we have been hesitant to put these tests into the main check
queue because with only a small number of nodes available (8
currently) it may lead to long delays merging code.

While jobs could go in the on-demand experimental pipeline, this
doesn't quite reflect the status of the jobs and nodes which are
operational.

I think that a separate queue to allow these jobs to run
automatically, but asynchronously to the regular check queue is a good
option here.  This will be a step to build a strong track-record for
the jobs without affecting the main gate, which should hopefully lead
to more interest and potentially more resources.

Change-Id: I77aac13521049496d43758121788aa44f0ecc990

commit_message:
zuul: arm64 pipeline

ARM64 testing is of interest to a number of projects.  For example:

 https://review.opendev.org/662456 : kolla
 https://review.opendev.org/676111 : diskimage-builder
 https://review.opendev.org/690798 : system-config (mirror tests)

However, we have been hesitant to put these tests into the main check
queue because with only a small number of nodes available (8
currently) it may lead to long delays merging code.

While jobs could go in the on-demand experimental pipeline, this
doesn't quite reflect the status of the jobs and nodes which are
operational.

I think that a separate queue to allow these jobs to run
automatically, but asynchronously to the regular check queue is a good
option here.  This will be a step to build a strong track-record for
the jobs without affecting the main gate, which should hopefully lead
to more interest and potentially more resources.

Change-Id: I77aac13521049496d43758121788aa44f0ecc990

[{'created': '2019-10-16 15:38:12.000000000', 'message': 'Switch to using IPXE

We are seeing failures in CI, where VMs will not boot. IPXE will
fetch the kernel via HTTP. The hope is that by using TCP instead
of UDP will prove more reliable.

Change-Id: I43d4a184a86fdce5382dd8555797f84439f5924a
'}]
commit_message:
Switch to using IPXE

We are seeing failures in CI, where VMs will not boot. IPXE will
fetch the kernel via HTTP. The hope is that by using TCP instead
of UDP will prove more reliable.

Change-Id: I43d4a184a86fdce5382dd8555797f84439f5924a

Remove v2 API docs

These are out-of-date (still have XML examples!), the v2 API is
deprecated and planned to be removed soon, and they've been
replaced by the v2 api-ref (which has not yet been removed).

Change-Id: I34f4e49f5ae4037277c136ee3e78d8eecee262cb

commit_message:
Enable check-approval in experimental pipeline

Define a check-approval job that runs check_approval.py, and
enable it in the experimental pipeline for now.

As a first step the job will run as a classic tox job on a worker
node, with an aggressive 6-min timeout.

Change-Id: Iaf8ffcb691f14e83843bf2079fabaa87776f0526

subject: Introduce tool to check PTL/liaison approval
messages:
[{'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-21 15:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-21 16:56:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-26 15:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-26 17:51:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Hello,

Nice feature!

However, I facing some issue that I'm not sure to see why they happen there:

```
$ tox -e check_approval -- 694844
check_approval develop-inst-noop: /home/hberaud/dev/openstack/releases
check_approval installed: alabaster==0.7.12,appdirs==1.4.3,attrs==19.3.0,Babel==2.7.0,bleach==3....
check_approval run-test-pre: PYTHONHASHSEED='1346733982'
check_approval run-test: commands[0] | python /home/hberaud/dev/openstack/releases/tools/check_approval.py 694844
✓ deliverables/_independent/pbr.yaml validated by hberaud@redhat.com
✓ deliverables/_independent/sphinx-feature-classification.yaml validated by hberaud@redhat.com
✓ deliverables/ussuri/castellan.yaml validated by hberaud@redhat.com
✓ deliverables/ussuri/futurist.yaml validated by hberaud@redhat.com
✕ deliverables/ussuri/oslo.cache.yaml not in oslo governance
```

```
$ tox -e check_approval -- 694024                                                                           
check_approval develop-inst-noop: /home/hberaud/dev/openstack/releases                                                                                                                               
check_approval installed: alabaster==0.7.12,appdirs==1.4.3,attrs==19.3.0,Babel==2.7.0,bleach==3....
check_approval run-test-pre: PYTHONHASHSEED='1258778212'
check_approval run-test: commands[0] | python /home/hberaud/dev/openstack/releases/tools/check_approval.py 694024
✕ deliverables/ussuri/oslo.utils.yaml not in oslo governance
```

Maybe I misunderstood something but in the both case I think we should have a positive result. 

In the first case I'm part of the oslo release liaison and in the second case I'm the author of this release and also member of the oslo release liaison, so I understand things correctly, normally the both tests should be ok.

Even by using the `--debug` mode I can't find why it fail...

I collect the following output:
```
DEBUG:__main__:Approvals: ['sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'mthode@mthode.org', 'thierry@openstack.org', 'hberaud@redhat.com', 'openstack@nemebean.com']
DEBUG:__main__:deliverables/_independent/pbr.yaml needs ['hberaud@redhat.com', 'openstack@nemebean.com']
```

Else, the following test seems ok:

```
$ tox -e check_approval -- 695375

commit_message:
Introduce tool to check PTL/liaison approval

This is the first step into automating PTL/liaison approval.
This tool will check that PTL/liaisons either authored the change or
approved it.

Change-Id: I1bbb371997e9e92f39eff47adb4d3d176af35de7

For sure this needs a rebase.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2019-12-12 12:53:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Oh, two things:
 > - when I checked devstack-gate a few days ago, it looks like those
 > 3 jobs are basically doing the same nowadays. The variables that
 > should differentiate them are not used. If anyone else can please
 > confirm that, it would be great.
 > - Are we keeping -dsvm- in the name because they are still legacy?

So i spend some time today investigating this and found out that the variables are used to disable different cinder services for each job

Eg: cinder-grenade-dsvm-mn-sub-volschbak[1] doesn't has c-sch service enabled and cinder-grenade-dsvm-mn-sub-bak[2] has c-sch enabled.

The services disabled for different jobs is described here[3]

[1] https://storage.bhs1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_831/695787/2/experimental/cinder-grenade-dsvm-mn-sub-volschbak/8310eeb/logs/old/devstacklog.txt.gz
[2] https://storage.gra1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_94a/695787/2/experimental/cinder-grenade-dsvm-mn-sub-bak/94a70d7/logs/old/devstacklog.txt.gz
[3] https://github.com/openstack/devstack-gate/blob/master/roles/test-matrix/files/features.yaml#L135-L151"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-12 13:08:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> > Oh, two things:
 > > - when I checked devstack-gate a few days ago, it looks like
 > those
 > > 3 jobs are basically doing the same nowadays. The variables that
 > > should differentiate them are not used. If anyone else can please
 > > confirm that, it would be great.
 > > - Are we keeping -dsvm- in the name because they are still
 > legacy?
 > 
 > So i spend some time today investigating this and found out that
 > the variables are used to disable different cinder services for
 > each job
 > 
 > Eg: cinder-grenade-dsvm-mn-sub-volschbak[1] doesn't has c-sch
 > service enabled and cinder-grenade-dsvm-mn-sub-bak[2] has c-sch
 > enabled.
 > 
 > The services disabled for different jobs is described here[3]

commit_message:
Move cinder grenade job to py3 and in cinder repo

below grenade jobs for cinder are present in opensatck-zuul-jobs
repo. These needs to run on py3 from Ussuri onwards and py2 for
stable/branch.

py2 version has been kept in opensatck-zuul-jobs and for ussuri
onwwards these has been migrated to cinder repo with py3 version.

- legacy-grenade-dsvm-cinder-mn-sub-bak
- legacy-grenade-dsvm-cinder-mn-sub-volbak
- legacy-grenade-dsvm-cinder-mn-sub-volschbak

Change-Id: I67d2504dd80214e615a45f605b0023ca6919fb73

commit_message:
builder: include environment when running an exec

Some container execs have an environment, let's make sure they are
included when running exec.

Closes-Bug: #1855932
Change-Id: Ic2e2c2d50f5883f7db28768ba215e74bcbf9fd8b

commit_message:
Improve detection of base path

On Ubuntu sys.prefix is set to '/usr' even though pip will install
packages to '/usr/local' when not using a virtualenv. This change fixes
the detection in this instance. Non standard install locations are not
currently supported.

Change-Id: I214e11e7d099d1b39041fdc6b91002e1929d9c00
Story: 2005510
Task: 30620

commit_message:
Create journal directory ahead

This patch makes it to create /var/log/journal directory before spawning collectd
container, because in some cases it might be created too late for successful container
startup.

Closes-Bug: #1856278
Change-Id: I0afaf3c8f7dafb6dc2f53e3a345cae27567b271b

commit_message:
Add Neutron network id to OVN LRPs

This patch is adding an external_id to the Logical_Router_Port
rows including the Neutron network ID.

The reason for this is that if we consume Octavia from Stein+ in
Rocky/Queens, this external id is missing and the OVN Octavia
driver (octavia_api) will not be able to apply the Load Balancers
to all the Logical Switches and Logical Routers where needed.

Note: This is a partial cherry-pick from
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668397/ since Octavia itself
does not exist in stable/rocky but can be made to work
with neutron's stable/rocky.

Change-Id: I4a0614afda8d2c2b8ccbb2583bc339a232fc802e
Co-Authored-By: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1855328
Related-Bug: #1794260
(cherry picked from commit aa4268a09470aea28f4a8c9f1062f32f057cb151)

commit_message:
Added option for osd failure domain

Allow the failure domain to be set to osd similar to the mon count
setting. This sets the CRUSH rule 0, default erasure profile, and makes
the related_osd count osds in place of relations. Finally, when in use
the first time status is run after passing the required osd count
clients are notified so any pending relations can continue.

Change-Id: I1b185b9f54ea9e15afe771e80fea10fb242da3c6
Closes-Bug: #1740961

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

Fixes #1734601

In case multiple zones have the same update timestamp (updated_at) the UI did
not show any zone and a JS console listed an error "Error: [ngRepeat:dupes]
Duplicates in a repeater are not allowed."
To fix it addTimestampIds needs to get the correct parameter order, i.e. pass
the name of the ID column before the timestamp column name.

Change-Id: Ib91f873e8f21b71a71b1684317db276b72ae8014

commit_message:
Fix list zones updated at same time

In case multiple zones have the same update timestamp (updated_at) the
UI did not show any zone and a JS console listed an error
"Error: [ngRepeat:dupes] Duplicates in a repeater are not allowed."
To fix it addTimestampIds needs to get the correct parameter order,
i.e. pass the name of the ID column before the timestamp column name.

Closes-Bug: 1734601

Change-Id: Ib91f873e8f21b71a71b1684317db276b72ae8014

commit_message:
deploy-steps: use lookup() to get pre|post_deployments_role variables

The syntax in place didn't allow to have an empty default for these 2
vars; which can happen in Queens if config-download is disabled.

Using the lookup module allows to set a default.

Change-Id: I0a42ebc93e53875ddcd32d801214eb1a993c4348
Closes-Bug: #1856314

commit_message:
Retry the connection to heat-api when 500 code

In a rare case like httpd reload by logrotate, heat-api returns
500 code. If this happens, trpleoclient can't get the status of
the stack even though the process is still on-going.

To handle this situation, tipleoclient should retry when it can't
get the stack information by 500 code.

Change-Id: I97a6825f4ff9f125eb597e5b7bd0c553c37e49e7
Closes-Bug: #1855633

commit_message:
Adds support for Ansible 2.8, bump mimimum to 2.6

Updates the minimum version of Ansible from 2.5 to 2.6, and the maximum
supported version from 2.7 to 2.8.

commit_message:
Change default value for NeutronPluginExtensions

After we switch default neutron driver to ovn also
NeutronPluginExtensions should contain dns because
"qos,port_security,dns" is default value for ovn.

commit_message:
fix imports of typeing module

This change adress the missing import of the typing module classes
and groups the import correctly to reflect if they are standard lib
or external depencies, depencies form other openstack project or
depencies form nova.

Change-Id: I8708a2170a6ea9229178bbba0f792b8aecfd3cd5
Closes-Bug: #1855934

commit_message:
Add CentOS/source aarch64 experimental job

Add kolla CentOS 7 source aarch64 building job.

Implements: blueprint aarch64-3rd-party-ci-kolla

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/698430

Change-Id: Ic32c19109d8521b93b7e124ac4ea9224767aad5c

commit_message:
l3 agent on network_hosts do dvr_snat, anywhere else dvr

With the change in queens of moving the neutron agents from
containers onto the network_hosts, if those hosts happen to
also be your nova_computes, VM's without a floating ip would
lose north/south network.

Checking for physical_host_group could make this patch work for
neutron_agents_containers on pike aswell, if we want to
backport it that far.

Change-Id: I6bb24a8719b3902d6f510c70705cdb63076a1a08
Signed-off-by: Erik Berg <openstack@slipsprogrammor.no>

Add heatclient lower constraint

commit_message:
Use APT pinning to set preferred version of RabbitMQ

We want RabbitMQ 3.7.10-1 for Ubuntu. So set it in one place which is
designed for such things instead of doing it everytime we want to
install it.

Change-Id: Ib2b2d4e392aaf77bcdec24f9f5551cdf15d32d91

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python2.7 support

As per the official python support timeline
set forth by the OpenStack TC [1][2], OpenStack
Train (in our case, python-manilaclient 1.29.x
series) is the last release that will support
python2.7.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I5b4dc1853d7e4f8f736dd2a22eb08bcfdeac3411

commit_message:
Add Networking-MLNX to Neutron-Base packages

The package is required for infiniband deployment to be installed
on containers: neutron-server, neutron-dhcp-agent and neutron-l3-agent.

Change-Id: I017b65c2032648fa0ac7126d4a06cd98cb7c33a0

commit_message:
Add netcontrold service for DPDK roles

netcontrold rebalances the overloaded queues within
available PMD threads to avoid packet loss. Add
support to enable this service in the DPDK deployments.

Change-Id: Ia0ec2a3db0626e9a93ef591d0bc4f3a53d98820f

[{'created': '2019-12-09 09:36:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix users/projects list when domain context is changed

In case of Keystone Multidomain setup, the project and users list
is empty when the domain context is changed. Horizon uses domain
scoped token for keystone api calls to get list of projects and users.
And domain scoped token cannot get information about projects and users
in other domains, the list is empty.

This patch modifies the use of domain scoped token only when domain
context is not modified.

The bug have 3 parts
1. Users are not listed on GUI in different domain
2. Projects are not listed on GUI in different domain
3. Gui hangs during creation of user/project using + option
This patch handles case 1 and 2.

Change-Id: Ibafe3e2eb3ee1ee5c9eb5d2a276a0edfa3e7c607
Partial-Bug: #1826114

commit_message:
Fix users/projects list when domain context is changed

In case of Keystone Multidomain setup, the project and users list
is empty when the domain context is changed. Horizon uses domain
scoped token for keystone api calls to get list of projects and users.
And domain scoped token cannot get information about projects and users
in other domains, the list is empty.

This patch modifies the use of domain scoped token only when domain
context is not modified.

The bug have 3 parts
1. Users are not listed on GUI in different domain
2. Projects are not listed on GUI in different domain
3. Gui hangs during creation of user/project using + option
This patch handles case 1 and 2.

Change-Id: Ibafe3e2eb3ee1ee5c9eb5d2a276a0edfa3e7c607
Partial-Bug: #1826114
Closes-Bug: #1830782

subject: Use regex to compare SQL strings with IN
messages: [{'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2019-12-11 16:07:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-12-12 15:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-12-13 08:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-11 16:07:18.000000000', 'message': 'Use regex to compare SQL strings with IN

SQLAlchemy 1.4 will be changing the method by which it
renders an IN expression such that the bound parameters
are not fully rendered until the statement is executed,
rather than when the statement is compiled into its initial
string form [1].   Adjust tests which are asserting the presence
of IN expressions based on the compiled form to allow for an
arbitrary expression within the parenthesis.

[1] https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/4645

Change-Id: I8640ad0cbd96647ed74678631479190146bd908e
'}]
commit_message:
Use regex to compare SQL strings with IN

SQLAlchemy 1.4 will be changing the method by which it
renders an IN expression such that the bound parameters
are not fully rendered until the statement is executed,
rather than when the statement is compiled into its initial
string form [1].   Adjust tests which are asserting the presence
of IN expressions based on the compiled form to allow for an
arbitrary expression within the parenthesis.

[1] https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/4645

Change-Id: I8640ad0cbd96647ed74678631479190146bd908e

commit_message:
Add prometheus-adapter

This will install the prometheus-adapter stable
helm chart. Requires monitoring_enabled=true.

The chart version can be configured using
prometheus_adapter_chart_tag and an option is
available to overwrite the default configuration
rules for a user defined ConfigMap referenced
by using prometheus_adapter_configmap label.

story: 2006765
task: 37278

Change-Id: I5b86f4455f88c8dbeac6e56942e1ca55f1d1726c
Signed-off-by: Diogo Guerra <diogo.filipe.tomas.guerra@cern.ch>
(cherry picked from commit 354575804f216fa24716a7f5256ceaf3241ba512)

Add Octavia anti-affinity parameters

commit_message:
Relax filtering in krb-service-principals jinja

The filtering added to fix Bug: #1821377 filters any
network without a VIP address. This filtering is to
agressive and cause deployment failure when a management
network without a VIP is used.

Change-Id: If189eb6fc0b2dc2c78323a7c08f7e303be2b6124
Resolves: rhbz#1778719
Closes-Bug: #1854846
(cherry picked from commit af79ae34ad9a3ed1581c0f6df91fa1e3ef0f8433)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-05 07:23:01.000000000', 'message': 'Enable user-specified port uuid

This feature provides a way for nova-compute services to avoid
deplicated port allocations when re-scheduling happens: in tempest
or bulk creating scenario, neutron-server timeouts occasionally happen
when nova-compute allocate ports in `_build_and_run` codes, and tasks
will be re-scheduled to other compute nodes. However, new compute nodes
know nothing about the allocated ports and will allocate ports from
neutron-server again. This usually leads to orphan ports. If nova-scheduler
service generates ports identifiers before requests passed to nova-compute
services, the existance checks for ports will be possible and already allocated
ports could be reused by nova-compute services.

Change-Id: I0d7a42d5e67b9bb6ab5cf751e4f3d1d946262be3
'}]
commit_message:
Enable user-specified port uuid

This feature provides a way for nova-compute services to avoid
deplicated port allocations when re-scheduling happens: in tempest
or bulk creating scenario, neutron-server timeouts occasionally happen
when nova-compute allocate ports in `_build_and_run` codes, and tasks
will be re-scheduled to other compute nodes. However, new compute nodes
know nothing about the allocated ports and will allocate ports from
neutron-server again. This usually leads to orphan ports. If nova-scheduler
service generates ports identifiers before requests passed to nova-compute
services, the existance checks for ports will be possible and already allocated
ports could be reused by nova-compute services.

Change-Id: I0d7a42d5e67b9bb6ab5cf751e4f3d1d946262be3

isn't resolved:

Closes-Bug: #1856191

commit_message:
Fix ironic-pxe container healthcheck

When calling Hiera, we need to use the following option or the parameter
isn't resolved:
-c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml

It'll fix the ironic pxe healthcheck.
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1856191

Change-Id: I79f5cc3010eed9a721eec61441a749ff984097f3

commit_message:
Add 5 placeholder db migration scripts for Train

There are two reasons for this:
1. For maybe some db migration scripts backporting for stable/train.
2. Convenience for internal development add db migration
scripts (can use the placeholder migration scripts),
and then can directly upgrade to the community latest version.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-11 01:14:43.000000000', 'message': "py3: Make seamless reloads work

Starting with Python 3.4, newly-created file descriptors are non-inheritable
[0], which causes trouble when we try to use a pipe for IPC. Fortunately, the
same PEP that implemented this change *also* provided a new API to mark file
descriptors as being inheritable -- so just do that.

While we're at it,

* Fix up the probe tests to work on py3
* Fix up the probe tests to work when policy-0 is erasure-coded
* Decode the bytes read so py3 doesn't log a b'pid'
* Log a warning if the read() is empty; something surely went wrong
  in the re-exec

[0] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0446/

Change-Id: I2a8a9f3dc78abb99bf9cbcf6b44c32ca644bb07b
Related-Change: I3e5229d2fb04be67e53533ff65b0870038accbb7
"}]
commit_message:
py3: Make seamless reloads work

Starting with Python 3.4, newly-created file descriptors are non-inheritable
[0], which causes trouble when we try to use a pipe for IPC. Fortunately, the
same PEP that implemented this change *also* provided a new API to mark file
descriptors as being inheritable -- so just do that.

While we're at it,

* Fix up the probe tests to work on py3
* Fix up the probe tests to work when policy-0 is erasure-coded
* Decode the bytes read so py3 doesn't log a b'pid'
* Log a warning if the read() is empty; something surely went wrong
  in the re-exec

[0] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0446/

Change-Id: I2a8a9f3dc78abb99bf9cbcf6b44c32ca644bb07b
Related-Change: I3e5229d2fb04be67e53533ff65b0870038accbb7

commit_message:
Access memcached via haproxy

Failure of single memcached instance now causes some delays in API
responses even with usage of oslo_cache.memcache_pool
Setting haproxy in front of memcache gives more reliable failover and
minimize delays in case of memcached failure.

Change-Id: Ic8dad765443a78ea03235da8f316c9de7ced8767

commit_message:
Add CephGrafana resource to the ControllerStorageNFS role

This change just adds the missing resource to include the missed
CephGrafana bits, fixing the ceph-dashboard deployment scenario.
In this review is also added a validation to make sure that both
ControllerStorage{Dashboard,Nfs} propertly inherit from Controller.

Change-Id: I0075bcb5318462555c7f9f96204ce037016f3e69
Closes-Bug: #1856060

commit_message:
Remove api in doc

Since now cyborg has its own API documentation in the
OpenStack api-ref landing page, it's better to remove api doc from
the doc page, so that users won't get confused.

Change-Id: Ib20015f8233fb780eb5d77112bcb9b302a8e3f72

commit_message:
Add support to configure virtlogd

Add a new class nova::compute::libvirt::virtlogd to manage virtlogd
configuration, which is located in /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf.

Change-Id: Iddfec9557ac93935744aa96b813eb54bda876deb

commit_message:
Keep pre-commit inline with hacking and fix whitespace

The flake8 hook for pre-commit installs its own flake8 which is
not what hacking is pinned to. This results in a bunch of errors.
By doing a local hook we can cause these to be the same.

There are flake8 exclusions in tox.ini that need to be used
in pre-commit. Also we should exclude svg files from the whitespace
modifications, because who cares.

Once those are fixed, running pre-commit -a fixes some whitespace
issues. While the normal use isn't to run -a - if someone does make
a patch that touches any of these they'll get erroneous unrelated
errors compared to their lower work - so fix all of the existing
issues, which are mostly space-at-end-of-line issues it seems.

Change-Id: I78e753492e99c03b30a0a691db3bd75ee3d289c9

commit_message:
Fix fernet bootstrap to properly advertise change

Current output from keystone-manage fernet_setup:

2019-12-12 10:30:46.956 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Created a new temporary key: /etc/keystone/fernet-keys/0.tmp
2019-12-12 10:30:46.958 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Become a valid new key: /etc/keystone/fernet-keys/0
2019-12-12 10:30:46.958 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Starting key rotation with 1 key files: ['/etc/keystone/fernet-keys/0']
2019-12-12 10:30:46.959 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Created a new temporary key: /etc/keystone/fernet-keys/0.tmp
2019-12-12 10:30:46.959 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Current primary key is: 0
2019-12-12 10:30:46.960 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Next primary key will be: 1
2019-12-12 10:30:46.960 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Promoted key 0 to be the primary: 1
2019-12-12 10:30:46.960 33 INFO keystone.common.fernet_utils [-] Become a valid new key: /etc/keystone/fernet-keys/0

We are checking for correct string [0], but doing wrong action.

[0]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/07d187eb4672e839093fec6b3f44f0f13756e410/keystone/common/fernet_utils.py#L184

Change-Id: If5d4c667abe898161734bfc08e3bfff9528b794f

commit_message:
Add testcase to verify disk size after snapshot created

testcase for clear volume

Added scenario manager class , inherits from tempest code plus
adding additional capabilites and clients .

The testcase run and create a volume from snapshot, attach it to instance
When the volume attached we check with lsblk the volume size.

Change-Id: I22c66cfd5bdf2a7e30583f60934dc94f093a62af

moving the devstack to py3 by default[2]. That will make grenade job
to perform upgrade from py2 to py3 which will not work (we have seen

jobs to py3 which is what we planned as part dropping the py2 support.

commit_message:
Migrate grenade jobs to py3

As part of community goal of dropping py27 support[1], we are
moving the devstack to py3 by default[2]. That will make grenade job
to perform upgrade from py2 to py3 which will not work (we have seen
the failure in neutron-grenade job).

To avoid existing grenade py2 job break, this commit moves grenade
jobs to py3 which is what we planned as part dropping the py2 support.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097/12
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010938.html

Change-Id: I822c7cb26f0d0f4e4d67df5d4b678853059cc0be

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 23:13:07.000000000', 'message': "Add functional recreate test for bug 1829479 and bug 1817833

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname). That failure is actually reported in bug 1817833.

NOTE(mriedem): Note that in this backport a simple version of
assertFlavorMatchesUsage is added since the original version from
change If6aa37d9b6b48791e070799ab026c816fda4441c is not in Rocky.

Change-Id: I69f52f1282c8361c9cdf90a523f3612139cb8423
Related-Bug: #1829479
Related-Bug: #1817833
(cherry picked from commit 2629d65fbc15d8698f98117e0d6072810f70da03)
(cherry picked from commit b18e42d20bd7d341e713292bdb179ae8e5530d33)
"}]
commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1829479 and bug 1817833

Change I7b8622b178d5043ed1556d7bdceaf60f47e5ac80 started deleting
the associated resource provider when a compute service is deleted.
However, the delete_resource_provider cascade=True logic only looks
for instances on the given compute service host being deleted which
will miss (1) allocations remaining from evacuated servers and
(2) unconfirmed migrations.

Attempting to delete the resource provider results in an
ResourceProviderInUse error which delete_resource_provider ignores
for legacy reasons. This results in the compute service being
deleted but the resource provider being orphaned. What's more,
attempting to restart the now-deleted compute service will fail
because nova-compute will try to create a new resource provider
with a new uuid but with the same name (based on the hypervisor
hostname). That failure is actually reported in bug 1817833.

NOTE(mriedem): Note that in this backport a simple version of
assertFlavorMatchesUsage is added since the original version from
change If6aa37d9b6b48791e070799ab026c816fda4441c is not in Rocky.

Change-Id: I69f52f1282c8361c9cdf90a523f3612139cb8423
Related-Bug: #1829479
Related-Bug: #1817833
(cherry picked from commit 2629d65fbc15d8698f98117e0d6072810f70da03)
(cherry picked from commit b18e42d20bd7d341e713292bdb179ae8e5530d33)

commit_message:
Add owner to allocations and create relevant policies

Add an owner to allocations. Depending on policy, a non-admin
can then create an allocation and have the owner set to their
project. Allocation processing then respects the owner.

Change-Id: I2965a4a601b9fa2c0212097da37b104a3e5514df
Story: #2006506
Task: #37540

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Panko is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/

Change-Id: I61488fc092ac11eb9f606d54c8e1a6e57851c4a0

subject: Remove use of deprecated config options for volume API selection
messages: [{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-12 17:02:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-12 17:03:50.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to volume-default-testing-v3'}, {'account_id': 14107, 'date': '2019-12-13 02:27:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-12 17:02:33.000000000', 'message': 'Remove use of deprecated config options for volume API selection

Tempest has moved the Volume APIs testing to v3 as default and can be run
under v2 API via catalog_type.
- https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:volume-default-testing-v3+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Below config options were deprecated since Rocky and now Tempest is going
to remove those (Needed-By patch):
    * ``CONF.volume-feature-enabled.api_v2``
    * ``CONF.volume-feature-enabled.api_v3``

Change-Id: Ib35bc0c4f9581857aba2fca4a17dc24e7424e8bd
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698754/
'}]
commit_message:
Remove use of deprecated config options for volume API selection

Tempest has moved the Volume APIs testing to v3 as default and can be run
under v2 API via catalog_type.
- https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:volume-default-testing-v3+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Below config options were deprecated since Rocky and now Tempest is going
to remove those (Needed-By patch):
    * ``CONF.volume-feature-enabled.api_v2``
    * ``CONF.volume-feature-enabled.api_v3``

Change-Id: Ib35bc0c4f9581857aba2fca4a17dc24e7424e8bd
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698754/

commit_message:
Add Octavia driver agent service

Initial addition of the octavia driver agent service which is required
for the Octavia OVN provider.

Conflicts:
    deployment/octavia/octavia-api-container-puppet.yaml
    
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697993/

Change-Id: Iddfbb649b3161a69a7d9a4a81b6913919d307d01
(cherry picked from commit 9e8d4e3c203fab396c653ffaad81ad6c869cc304)
(cherry picked from commit 58c36233bc8c72805ad3640798eadf07b69e6684)

commit_message:
Actually test rescue in the standalone job

The current test only makes sure the node can be pinged and passes
happily if rescue fails, as long as the ramdisk stays online.

Change-Id: Ib4946974713ccf5fccb38359987ce6e7573e07e0

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-10 15:28:26.000000000', 'message': 'Update nova os-server-external-events response logic

When the power update was written [1] to use nova's
os-server-external-events API, the internals of that method had a bug
(see the related bug). Fortunately, the code was written so it works
against the nova side with or without the fix. However, for the sake of
propriety, this commit refactors the code to reflect nova's behavior
more accurately.

Specifically: Previously, it was impossible for nova to respond 207 when
the client sent a single event (as ironic does). The code path
accounting for that 207 existed, but always returned True ("success")
rather than returning False ("failure") if the event code was >=400.
Fortunately, the return value is only ever used in unit test, not
production code, so it didn't matter.

With this commit, the 207 path is handled correctly, such that the
method "succeeds" if the event code is <400 (which would never happen in
real life) and "fails" if the event code is >=400.

[1] I6d105524e1645d9a40dfeae2850c33cf2d110826
Related-Bug: #1855752

Change-Id: I13744175127e9956fb785a9efc82193c333b2bdc
'}]
commit_message:
Update nova os-server-external-events response logic

When the power update was written [1] to use nova's
os-server-external-events API, the internals of that method had a bug
(see the related bug). Fortunately, the code was written so it works
against the nova side with or without the fix. However, for the sake of
propriety, this commit refactors the code to reflect nova's behavior
more accurately.

Specifically: Previously, it was impossible for nova to respond 207 when
the client sent a single event (as ironic does). The code path
accounting for that 207 existed, but always returned True ("success")
rather than returning False ("failure") if the event code was >=400.
Fortunately, the return value is only ever used in unit test, not
production code, so it didn't matter.

With this commit, the 207 path is handled correctly, such that the
method "succeeds" if the event code is <400 (which would never happen in
real life) and "fails" if the event code is >=400.

[1] I6d105524e1645d9a40dfeae2850c33cf2d110826
Related-Bug: #1855752

Change-Id: I13744175127e9956fb785a9efc82193c333b2bdc

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Overall LGTM, but I'm not sure about the "import six" there,
 > @gouthamr what do you think?

Hmm, That's nice catch. I used `import six` because of python 2.x compatibility. in python 2, To check varirable is string use `isinstance(s, basestring)`, but in python 3 `isinstance(s, str)`. However as we know, we don't need to provide python 2.x compatability anymore. So I think I can change with `isinstance(s, str)` with no import six. How do you think about that @gouthamr, @amit?'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2019-12-09 21:43:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)

> Hmm, That's nice catch. I used `import six` because of python 2.x compatibility. in python 2, > To check varirable is string use `isinstance(s, basestring)`, but in python 3 `isinstance(s, str)`. However as we know, we don't need to provide python 2.x compatability anymore. So I think I can change with `isinstance(s, str)` with no import six. How do you think about that @gouthamr, @amit?

Hi Amit, Woohyung:

We'll likely rip out python2 testing this week [1], so, I agree we don't need python2 compatibility. However, after removing the use of 'six', for this patch not to fail on the CI, it needs to depend on [1] while it hasn't merged. 

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/691134/"}, {'account_id': 30722, 'date': '2019-12-11 00:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 30722, 'date': '2019-12-11 00:19:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 21884, 'date': '2019-12-11 00:21:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-11 07:39:58.000000000', 'message': "Make extra_specs value as case insensitive

Extra_specs are key/value pair for filtering backends. If some share_type
has extra_specs that 'storage_protocol=NFS', matching with 'CIFS' failed
but 'NFS' succeeds. However, if we trying to match with 'nfs' it failed
unintentaionally. Make extra_specs value as case insensitive.

Change-Id: I51376d1b13a5300cfdbe19f6eadc341db45efcd6
"}, {'created': '2019-10-27 08:53:12.000000000', 'message': 'Make extra_specs value as case-insensitive

Currently the value of extra_specs is not case-insenstive. If some
share_type has extra_specs that is `storage_protocol=NFS`, It will
not be filtered by `storage_protocol=nfs`. Make extra_specs value
as case-insensitive.

Change-Id: I51376d1b13a5300cfdbe19f6eadc341db45efcd6
Closes-Bug: #1850029

commit_message:
Make extra_specs value as case-insensitive

Currently the value of extra_specs is not case-insenstive. If some
share_type has extra_specs that is `storage_protocol=NFS`, It will
not be filtered by `storage_protocol=nfs`. Make extra_specs value
as case-insensitive.

Change-Id: I51376d1b13a5300cfdbe19f6eadc341db45efcd6
Closes-Bug: #1850029

commit_message:
Adds --before archive parameter to cron job

Adds --before to the archive command based on age parameter provided.
If added, it will run with:
--before `date --date='today - #{params[:age]} days' +\\%F`

Change-Id: I3af194696b87f6e17e9576c48f69ec7dde2640fd
(cherry picked from commit 2716ce36e0ed73dcd9389d774b435fb5d21b53cd)
(cherry picked from commit 7d002fd713627e6b87f1db6eac77403c629765d0)

This is new feature support to me, not a bug. This is adding new flavor extra spec and image property support to enable a feature. I don't care if the original spec said it should have been done back in Kilo or Queens or whatever, it wasn't done, and lack of a feature is not a bug. I wouldn't backport this either way, at least upstream. So I think this should be tracked with a blueprint upstream."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-08-07 16:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
support pci numa affinity policies in flavor and image

This addresses bug #1795920 by adding support for
defining a pci numa affinity policy via the flavor
extra specs or image metadata properties enabling
the policies to be applied to neutron sriov port
including hardware offloaded ovs.

Closes-Bug: #1795920
Related-Bug: #1805891
Implements: blueprint vm-scoped-sriov-numa-affinity
Change-Id: Ibd62b24c2bd2dd208d0f804378d4e4f2bbfdaed6

recheck'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-12-06 07:06:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

One question on uncapping.

Django minor bumps usually drop deprecated features. Horizon team mainly just follows Django LTS releases and does not follow changes in every Django minor releases. If we uncap Django version, does it mean that the upper-constraints job tries to update the Django entry in upper-constraints every time a newer Django comes? I wonder how it should be handled.'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-12-06 07:20:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-12-06 10:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-06 12:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-06 12:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> One question on uncapping.
 > 
 > Django minor bumps usually drop deprecated features. Horizon team
 > mainly just follows Django LTS releases and does not follow changes
 > in every Django minor releases. If we uncap Django version, does it
 > mean that the upper-constraints job tries to update the Django
 > entry in upper-constraints every time a newer Django comes? I
 > wonder how it should be handled.

Good question.

1) Tell them to stop doing that! :)
2) I think we may need to add Django to blacklist.txt to keep the automatic updates from happening. Maybe prometheanfire can confirm that.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-07 23:45:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck

 > changes

 > > entry in upper-constraints every time a newer Django comes? I

 > Good question.
 > 
 > 1) Tell them to stop doing that! :)
 > 2) I think we may need to add Django to blacklist.txt to keep the

any update on this comment?
Do we need to Django to 'blacklist.txt'"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-12-11 05:00:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > One question on uncapping.
 > 
 > Django minor bumps usually drop deprecated features. Horizon team
 > mainly just follows Django LTS releases and does not follow changes
 > in every Django minor releases. If we uncap Django version, does it
 > mean that the upper-constraints job tries to update the Django
 > entry in upper-constraints every time a newer Django comes? I
 > wonder how it should be handled.
>
> Good question.
>
> 1) Tell them to stop doing that! :) 2) I think we may need to add
> Django to blacklist.txt to keep the automatic updates from
> happening. Maybe prometheanfire can confirm that.

Thanks Sean.
Approach 2 looks practical to me. I think we can discuss pros and cons of using blacklist.txt later.
Reagrding 1, Django already defined its roadmap along with the future versions and the current versioning strategy is being used for long, so I don't think it can happen soon."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-12-11 05:00:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-12-11 20:48:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-12-11 21:20:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

There was a lot of useful conversation in the review. please add it to the commit message. 

The take away I have from reading the lifecycle here https://www.djangoproject.com/download/

is that we want to update the cap to < 3.0 (or < 3.2). depending on the decision on whether horizon wants to follow 2.2 LTS or not. 

So a new cap might be the better solution.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-12-11 21:20:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

the downside of blacklist is that you would also not get any micro patch version updates, which we *do* want to get in IMHO. 

blacklist is really just for test-only lint tooling and django is not in that area.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-12-12 18:51:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-12-12 18:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I got explained that there is a follow-up patch  fine by me then'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-12-12 18:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-12-12 18:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-12-12 19:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-23 19:50:15.000000000', 'message': "Fix listing deleted servers with a marker

Change I1aa3ca6cc70cef65d24dec1e7db9491c9b73f7ab in Queens,
which was backported through to Newton, introduced a regression
when listing deleted servers with a marker because it assumes
that if BuildRequestList.get_by_filters does not raise
MarkerNotFound that the marker was found among the build requests
and does not account for that get_by_filters method short-circuiting
if filtering servers with deleted/cleaned/limit=0. The API code
then nulls out the marker which means you'll continue to get the
marker instance back in the results even though you shouldn't,
and that can cause an infinite loop in some client-side tooling like
nova's CLI:

  nova list --deleted --limit -1

This fixes the bug by raising MarkerNotFound from
BuildRequestList.get_by_filters if we have a marker but are
short-circuiting and returning early from the method based on
limit or filters.

Change-Id: Ic2b19c2aa06b3059ab0344b6ac56ffd62b3f755d
Closes-Bug: #1849409

commit_message:
Fix listing deleted servers with a marker

Change I1aa3ca6cc70cef65d24dec1e7db9491c9b73f7ab in Queens,
which was backported through to Newton, introduced a regression
when listing deleted servers with a marker because it assumes
that if BuildRequestList.get_by_filters does not raise
MarkerNotFound that the marker was found among the build requests
and does not account for that get_by_filters method short-circuiting
if filtering servers with deleted/cleaned/limit=0. The API code
then nulls out the marker which means you'll continue to get the
marker instance back in the results even though you shouldn't,
and that can cause an infinite loop in some client-side tooling like
nova's CLI:

  nova list --deleted --limit -1

This fixes the bug by raising MarkerNotFound from
BuildRequestList.get_by_filters if we have a marker but are
short-circuiting and returning early from the method based on
limit or filters.

Change-Id: Ic2b19c2aa06b3059ab0344b6ac56ffd62b3f755d
Closes-Bug: #1849409
(cherry picked from commit df03499843aa7fd6089bd4d07b9d0eb5a8c14b47)
(cherry picked from commit 03a2508362ecf50463d0659142312a30d0fb91f3)
(cherry picked from commit 6038455e1dafeaf8ccfdd4be9e993beea3c9fb45)
(cherry picked from commit c84846dbf93588e5420b3565d163c0393443e6d6)

commit_message:
Check for existance of ethtool and iproute2

It's good to check for tools before launching them. The common practise
is used in openstack-ansible/scripts/log-collect.sh

commit_message:
Add deploy_steps_tasks to PER_TASK_STEPS

deploy_steps_tasks will now be written out in per step files in the
config download directory. This will allow including the task files for
a specific step only at that step, and saving time by not having to skip
so many tasks.

Change-Id: Id5fdb4dd1a6290d1097d2d81523161c87ab6d4dd

commit_message:
Render containerized-prepare-parameters.yaml during upgrade if not found.

Generally, if we upgrade from a containerized undercloud the
containers-prepare-paramters.yaml file will be already present (as
it is being rendered during the undercloud-deploy). However, if we
upgrade the Undercloud from Queens (non-containerized) to Rocky
(containerized) the file won't be present. We need to render it
during the container-update role so we can set the right values.

Change-Id: I3fd411ef753bdd1f4ce5d6befa726d82e9073458
Related-Bug: #1855856

commit_message:
Remove ceph backend by default for gnocchi

Ceph requires some additional setup, and just defaulting to ceph
will make a deployment fail, if ceph is not set up.

Change-Id: I83f57cb71f304c14aa4bacc4a57a9930bd168150

[{'created': '2019-12-11 15:33:50.000000000', 'message': 'scale: fixes for compute scale down

- Force fact gathering so that we're ensured to have the proper FQDN
- Update start squence so that our scale down process is not starting
  from irrelevant steps
- correct list evaluation. The compute service argument should have one
  item in the list. Prior to this change it was expecting zero items,
  which was causing the removal tasks to skip.

Co-Authored-By: "Cedric Jeanneret (Tengu) <cjeanner@redhat.com>"
Co-Authored-By: "Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>"
Co-Authored-By: "Kevin Carter (cloudnull) <kecarter@redhat.com>"

commit_message:
scale: fixes for compute scale down

- Force fact gathering so that we're ensured to have the proper FQDN
- Update start squence so that our scale down process is not starting
  from irrelevant steps
- correct list evaluation. The compute service argument should have one
  item in the list. Prior to this change it was expecting zero items,
  which was causing the removal tasks to skip.

Co-Authored-By: "Cedric Jeanneret (Tengu) <cjeanner@redhat.com>"
Co-Authored-By: "Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>"
Co-Authored-By: "Kevin Carter (cloudnull) <kecarter@redhat.com>"

Change-Id: I7c1615685718924e872a2f9173b15c63bba8c482
Closes-Bug: #1856062

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-23 19:50:15.000000000', 'message': "Add functional regression test for bug 1849409

Change I1aa3ca6cc70cef65d24dec1e7db9491c9b73f7ab in Queens,
which was backported through to Newton, introduced a regression
when listing deleted servers with a marker because it assumes
that if BuildRequestList.get_by_filters does not raise
MarkerNotFound that the marker was found among the build requests
and does not account for that get_by_filters method short-circuiting
if filtering servers with deleted/cleaned/limit=0. The API code
then nulls out the marker which means you'll continue to get the
marker instance back in the results even though you shouldn't,
and that can cause an infinite loop in some client-side tooling like
nova's CLI:

  nova list --deleted --limit -1

This adds a functional recreate test for the regression which will
be updated when the bug is fixed.

NOTE(mriedem): In this backport the test is modified to create the
server with a specific network id to avoid a NetworkAmbiguous error
which is probably due to some missing NeutronFixture sugar added
in Rocky.

Change-Id: I324193129acb6ac739133c7e76920762a8987a84
Related-Bug: #1849409
(cherry picked from commit 45c2752f2ce08b314012eff044b01aa7d626b43d)
(cherry picked from commit 727d942b2830fb6970d99507f2b5eb1a28df01b2)
(cherry picked from commit 47caaccd4a03660d7df144f2eadd821d36baeaa8)
(cherry picked from commit 56c5753747564c1a93958f3094785d2e8e4b6598)

that if BuildRequestList.get_by_filters does not raise
MarkerNotFound that the marker was found among the build requests
and does not account for that get_by_filters method short-circuiting
if filtering servers with deleted/cleaned/limit=0. The API code
then nulls out the marker which means you'll continue to get the
marker instance back in the results even though you shouldn't,
and that can cause an infinite loop in some client-side tooling like
nova's CLI:

  nova list --deleted --limit -1

This adds a functional recreate test for the regression which will
be updated when the bug is fixed.

NOTE(mriedem): In this backport the test is modified to create the
server without networking to avoid a NetworkAmbiguous error
which is probably due to some missing NeutronFixture sugar added

Change-Id: I324193129acb6ac739133c7e76920762a8987a84

commit_message:
Add functional regression test for bug 1849409

Change I1aa3ca6cc70cef65d24dec1e7db9491c9b73f7ab in Queens,
which was backported through to Newton, introduced a regression
when listing deleted servers with a marker because it assumes
that if BuildRequestList.get_by_filters does not raise
MarkerNotFound that the marker was found among the build requests
and does not account for that get_by_filters method short-circuiting
if filtering servers with deleted/cleaned/limit=0. The API code
then nulls out the marker which means you'll continue to get the
marker instance back in the results even though you shouldn't,
and that can cause an infinite loop in some client-side tooling like
nova's CLI:

  nova list --deleted --limit -1

This adds a functional recreate test for the regression which will
be updated when the bug is fixed.

NOTE(mriedem): In this backport the test is modified to create the
server without networking to avoid a NetworkAmbiguous error
which is probably due to some missing NeutronFixture sugar added
in Rocky.

Change-Id: I324193129acb6ac739133c7e76920762a8987a84
Related-Bug: #1849409
(cherry picked from commit 45c2752f2ce08b314012eff044b01aa7d626b43d)
(cherry picked from commit 727d942b2830fb6970d99507f2b5eb1a28df01b2)
(cherry picked from commit 47caaccd4a03660d7df144f2eadd821d36baeaa8)
(cherry picked from commit 08337cccb060d0b3cad388004c1f802d5d053813)

commit_message:
Enable image import conversion & image output format

Glance image conversion configuration is not enabled by
puppet-glance in glance-image-import.conf.

Adding image_import_plugins & output format parameters to enable
glance image conversion.

Change-Id: I098aa0cabf2518b8861d5b58b885d9bdef54a7f6
Closes-Bug: #1807366
(cherry picked from commit 091c01b7b8698975de77ccc5b22e2581cbcf64b8)
(cherry picked from commit a245923a28baa1445311f6e3729eca990810f208)

[{'created': '2019-12-11 16:25:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add LEAPP_SKIP_CHECK_OS_RELEASE variable in UC upgrade.

The upgrade from RHEL7.7 might be supported by Leapp when
passing the LEAPP_SKIP_CHECK_OS_RELEASE option. This patch
adds the option to enable it if needed when executing the
opearating system upgrade in the Undercloud.

Change-Id: If62f3ab18289508f0b8ef372d64f84dec0c56610
'}]
commit_message:
Add LEAPP_SKIP_CHECK_OS_RELEASE variable in UC upgrade.

The upgrade from RHEL7.7 might be supported by Leapp when
passing the LEAPP_SKIP_CHECK_OS_RELEASE option. This patch
adds the option to enable it if needed when executing the
opearating system upgrade in the Undercloud.

Change-Id: If62f3ab18289508f0b8ef372d64f84dec0c56610

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-12 20:06:44.000000000', 'message': "List SG rules which belongs to tenant's SG

In case when user's security group contains rules created e.g.
by admin, and such rules has got admin's tenant as tenant_id,
owner of security group should be able to see those rules.
Some time ago this was addressed for request:

GET /v2.0/security-groups/<sec_group_id>

But it is also required to behave in same way for

GET /v2.0/security-group-rules

So this patch fixes this behaviour for listing of security
group rules.
To achieve that this patch also adds new policy rule:
ADMIN_OWNER_OR_SG_OWNER which is similar to already existing
ADMIN_OWNER_OR_NETWORK_OWNER used e.g. for listing or creating
ports.

Change-Id: I09114712582d2d38d14cf1683b87a8ce3a8e8c3c
Closes-Bug: #1824248

commit_message:
List SG rules which belongs to tenant's SG

In case when user's security group contains rules created e.g.
by admin, and such rules has got admin's tenant as tenant_id,
owner of security group should be able to see those rules.
Some time ago this was addressed for request:

GET /v2.0/security-groups/<sec_group_id>

But it is also required to behave in same way for

GET /v2.0/security-group-rules

So this patch fixes this behaviour for listing of security
group rules.
To achieve that this patch also adds new policy rule:
ADMIN_OWNER_OR_SG_OWNER which is similar to already existing
ADMIN_OWNER_OR_NETWORK_OWNER used e.g. for listing or creating
ports.

Change-Id: I09114712582d2d38d14cf1683b87a8ce3a8e8c3c
Closes-Bug: #1824248

commit_message:
Don't hardcode Python versions in test

As noted in change If8184c190e76d8cefb5b097f8fa8cb7564207103, the format
of an internal error message changed in Python 3. There's no need to
manually list each of these versions though - just ensure it's Python 3.

Change-Id: Ie1a97d251c6098054bdc963acf53c3182b52b2aa
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1855493

subject: Fix reference cycle caused by deprecated sample override
messages: [{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-11-18 20:23:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-26 10:27:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-12 20:59:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nThis has been merged in Stein for a while, so it should definitely be in Train.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-18 20:23:22.000000000', 'message': "Fix reference cycle caused by deprecated sample override

In the sample policy generator, we create a rule that maps the
deprecated name of a policy to the new rule name. For example:

identity:old_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

However, in the policy code, if we see an override of a deprecated
name and no override for the new name, we apply the value of the
deprecated name to the new name. In the above case, this results
in us creating a rule that looks like:

identity:new_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

which is a circular reference and nonsense.

To fix this, I added a check to the deprecated rule logic that looks
for instances where the old override is just a reference to the new
rule. If that's the case, then we don't need to do anything because
it's already doing the right thing.

Change-Id: Ifd14993bc84e83c13abab3456fbf670c06e5806f
Closes-Bug: 1843931
(cherry picked from commit 82a2c8d8b71896b1f8b7f33c560681367ae76755)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix reference cycle caused by deprecated sample override

In the sample policy generator, we create a rule that maps the
deprecated name of a policy to the new rule name. For example:

identity:old_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

However, in the policy code, if we see an override of a deprecated
name and no override for the new name, we apply the value of the
deprecated name to the new name. In the above case, this results
in us creating a rule that looks like:

identity:new_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

which is a circular reference and nonsense.

To fix this, I added a check to the deprecated rule logic that looks
for instances where the old override is just a reference to the new
rule. If that's the case, then we don't need to do anything because
it's already doing the right thing.

Change-Id: Ifd14993bc84e83c13abab3456fbf670c06e5806f
Closes-Bug: 1843931
(cherry picked from commit 82a2c8d8b71896b1f8b7f33c560681367ae76755)

[{'created': '2019-12-06 16:42:18.000000000', 'message': "functional: Remove 'api' parameter

Pretty much every test case in 'nova.tests.functional' defines an 'api'
attribute, and many define an 'admin_api' attribute. We can pull these
from the class rather than explicitly passing them to helpers. Rework
things so this happens.

Note that the bulk of the changes here are in the
'nova/tests/functional/integrated_helpers.py' file. The rest of the
changes were auto-generated using the following script (my sed-fu is
non-existent):

  $ cd nova/tests/functional
  $ python3
  >>> import glob
  >>> import re
  >>> pattern = r'_state_change\((\n\s+)?self\.(admin_)?api,\s+'
  >>> replace = r'_state_change(\1'
  >>> for path in glob.glob('*.py') + glob.glob('*/*.py'):
  ...     with open(path) as fh:
  ...         data = fh.read()
  ...     new = re.sub(pattern, replace, data, flags=re.MULTILINE)
  ...     if new != data:
  ...         with open(path, 'w') as fh:
  ...             fh.write(new)
  ...
  >>> quit()

(ditto for the other substitutions)

Some manual fixups were required after, which pre-commit highlighted :)

Change-Id: I8c96b337f32148f8f5899c9b87af331b1fa41424
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
functional: Remove 'api' parameter

Pretty much every test case in 'nova.tests.functional' defines an 'api'
attribute, and many define an 'admin_api' attribute. We can pull these
from the class rather than explicitly passing them to helpers. Rework
things so this happens.

Note that the bulk of the changes here are in the
'nova/tests/functional/integrated_helpers.py' file. The rest of the
changes were auto-generated using the following script (my sed-fu is
non-existent):

  $ cd nova/tests/functional
  $ python3
  >>> import glob
  >>> import re
  >>> pattern = r'_state_change\((\n\s+)?self\.(admin_)?api,\s+'
  >>> replace = r'_state_change(\1'
  >>> for path in glob.glob('*.py') + glob.glob('*/*.py'):
  ...     with open(path) as fh:
  ...         data = fh.read()
  ...     new = re.sub(pattern, replace, data, flags=re.MULTILINE)
  ...     if new != data:
  ...         with open(path, 'w') as fh:
  ...             fh.write(new)
  ...
  >>> quit()

(ditto for the other substitutions)

Some manual fixups were required after, which pre-commit highlighted :)

Change-Id: I8c96b337f32148f8f5899c9b87af331b1fa41424
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

subject: Suppress deprecation warnings in oslopolicy-list-redundant
messages: [{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-11-18 20:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-21 17:05:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-12 20:38:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-18 20:26:11.000000000', 'message': 'Suppress deprecation warnings in oslopolicy-list-redundant

When running the tool against a project with a lot of deprecated
policies, the deprecation warnings overwhelm the important output
from the tool. Since checking for deprecations isn't the purpose of
this tool, let's just suppress warnings and limit the output to the
list of redundant policy rules that the user cares about.

I will note that the suppress_deprecation_warnings member is marked
as test only, but that was targeted at consumers of oslo.policy
rather than oslo.policy itself. I could also argue that we're
"testing" for redundant policies here, but that feels like semantic
hair splitting. :-)

Change-Id: I194af14ebd341366dbb1dd033654739a7f3d085c
Partial-Bug: 1836568
(cherry picked from commit 5d3aeb53a9f3686353e0740c1891bd0e66e90650)
'}]
commit_message:
Suppress deprecation warnings in oslopolicy-list-redundant

When running the tool against a project with a lot of deprecated
policies, the deprecation warnings overwhelm the important output
from the tool. Since checking for deprecations isn't the purpose of
this tool, let's just suppress warnings and limit the output to the
list of redundant policy rules that the user cares about.

I will note that the suppress_deprecation_warnings member is marked
as test only, but that was targeted at consumers of oslo.policy
rather than oslo.policy itself. I could also argue that we're
"testing" for redundant policies here, but that feels like semantic
hair splitting. :-)

Change-Id: I194af14ebd341366dbb1dd033654739a7f3d085c
Partial-Bug: 1836568
(cherry picked from commit 5d3aeb53a9f3686353e0740c1891bd0e66e90650)

commit_message:
trivial: Resolve (most) flake8 3.x issues

A future change will bump flake8 to 3.x. See off most of the issues that
this will introduce now, with the exception of some missing typing
imports in 'nova/virt/hardware.py' - fixing those here with the current
version of flake8 would actually raise an error about unused imports.

Change-Id: I9480ac1749d448efe4f415f5e80ff9b9837216b6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

subject: Modernize policy checker
messages: [{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-11-18 20:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-26 10:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-12 20:36:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-18 20:27:11.000000000', 'message': 'Modernize policy checker

Without this patch, the policy checker issues a 'failed' result when
checking a system-scoped sample token against a policy string like
"role:admin and system_scope:all", because the policy checker does not
understand the 'system_scope' attribute that is now in oslo.context[1]
and wasn't parsing the "system" scope object from the sample token.
Similarly, it fails on a string like "user_id:%(user_id)s" because it
never looked up the user_id from the sample token. This change updates
the policy checker to understand token contexts and policies like these
so that more of the policy defaults in keystone, and soon other
projects, will pass. This also adds a new system-scoped sample token to
check against.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/530509

Change-Id: I02fbbc99d28aa5c787133f530f6e968341107bf7
(cherry picked from commit 99daead510eac0e2ca1a07b13e421987541efc36)
'}]
commit_message:
Modernize policy checker

Without this patch, the policy checker issues a 'failed' result when
checking a system-scoped sample token against a policy string like
"role:admin and system_scope:all", because the policy checker does not
understand the 'system_scope' attribute that is now in oslo.context[1]
and wasn't parsing the "system" scope object from the sample token.
Similarly, it fails on a string like "user_id:%(user_id)s" because it
never looked up the user_id from the sample token. This change updates
the policy checker to understand token contexts and policies like these
so that more of the policy defaults in keystone, and soon other
projects, will pass. This also adds a new system-scoped sample token to
check against.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/530509

Change-Id: I02fbbc99d28aa5c787133f530f6e968341107bf7
(cherry picked from commit 99daead510eac0e2ca1a07b13e421987541efc36)

commit_message:
Replace volbak grenade py2 job with py3

Currently projects are dropping py2 support and changing master code
to be compatible with only py3.
The grenade jobs when trying to upgrade from py2 to py3 fail[1].

This patch replaces the current running py2 job with py3 job in master.

[1] failure in legacy-grenade-dsvm-cinder-mn-sub-volbak job
https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_9f6/661676/16/check/legacy-grenade-dsvm-cinder-mn-sub-volbak/9f631aa/logs/screen-q-dhcp.txt.gz

Change-Id: I25a4c23fe93b8bbc957ce10bc6ff9aef3ec1b1f8

With the change in queens of moving the neutron agents from
containers onto the network_hosts, if those hosts happen to
also be your nova_computes, VM's without a floating ip would
lose north/south network.

Checking for physical_host_group could make this patch work for
neutron_agents_containers on pike aswell, if we want to
backport it that far.

Change-Id: I6bb24a8719b3902d6f510c70705cdb63076a1a08
Signed-off-by: Erik Berg <openstack@slipsprogrammor.no>
(cherry picked from commit edf0a25ca2e78658f06a2394a4ded60b49232bca)
"}]
commit_message:
l3 agent on network_hosts do dvr_snat, anywhere else dvr

With the change in queens of moving the neutron agents from
containers onto the network_hosts, if those hosts happen to
also be your nova_computes, VM's without a floating ip would
lose north/south network.

Checking for physical_host_group could make this patch work for
neutron_agents_containers on pike aswell, if we want to
backport it that far.

Change-Id: I6bb24a8719b3902d6f510c70705cdb63076a1a08
Signed-off-by: Erik Berg <openstack@slipsprogrammor.no>
(cherry picked from commit edf0a25ca2e78658f06a2394a4ded60b49232bca)

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Depends-On: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e
Change-Id: I8c487c3fb4239d27c9e6d3637a8718d2bb875d29

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Depends-On: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e
Change-Id: I1853f09568e7e713d0404d74be86f7629f155da5

when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be

subject: Fix reference cycle caused by deprecated sample override
messages:
[{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-09-24 13:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2019-09-24 14:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:22:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Bleh, bandit. I've backported https://review.opendev.org/#/c/684378/ which should hopefully fix this."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-09-24 19:05:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck bandit cap has merged'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-09-25 09:40:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-12 21:00:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This shouldn't have been merged in Stein before the Train backport was merged."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-24 13:21:16.000000000', 'message': "Fix reference cycle caused by deprecated sample override

In the sample policy generator, we create a rule that maps the
deprecated name of a policy to the new rule name. For example:

identity:old_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

However, in the policy code, if we see an override of a deprecated
name and no override for the new name, we apply the value of the
deprecated name to the new name. In the above case, this results
in us creating a rule that looks like:

identity:new_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

which is a circular reference and nonsense.

To fix this, I added a check to the deprecated rule logic that looks
for instances where the old override is just a reference to the new
rule. If that's the case, then we don't need to do anything because
it's already doing the right thing.

Change-Id: Ifd14993bc84e83c13abab3456fbf670c06e5806f
Closes-Bug: 1843931
(cherry picked from commit 82a2c8d8b71896b1f8b7f33c560681367ae76755)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix reference cycle caused by deprecated sample override

In the sample policy generator, we create a rule that maps the
deprecated name of a policy to the new rule name. For example:

identity:old_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

However, in the policy code, if we see an override of a deprecated
name and no override for the new name, we apply the value of the
deprecated name to the new name. In the above case, this results
in us creating a rule that looks like:

identity:new_rule: rule:identity:new_rule

which is a circular reference and nonsense.

To fix this, I added a check to the deprecated rule logic that looks
for instances where the old override is just a reference to the new
rule. If that's the case, then we don't need to do anything because
it's already doing the right thing.

Change-Id: Ifd14993bc84e83c13abab3456fbf670c06e5806f
Closes-Bug: 1843931
(cherry picked from commit 82a2c8d8b71896b1f8b7f33c560681367ae76755)

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Depends-On: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e

Change-Id: I792d057fab99ed6226a10d8912be274a7192c2b1

commit_message:
PowerMax and VNX Manila - Read only policy is not working correctly

Fix to ensure that hosts that are given access to a share i.e read only,
will always precede '-0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0' in Access host.  Any host after
this string will be denied access.

Change-Id: I813191abc592703d6aa7ea55c5be81d1a6089f39
Closes-Bug: #1845147

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Depends-On: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e
Change-Id: Id299ea1d104bc95a49efa3c1cb5e43b0a43fcdd3

suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Depends-On: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e
Change-Id: If0d8491ef25c1ed1631f9742ebc9656cea864119

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Depends-On: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e
Change-Id: I07419b0100ae680aa124f0c0024fedff29a30476

[{'created': '2019-12-12 10:36:44.000000000', 'message': 'Use constraints for docs tox target

In Stein the docs target started to fail when new release of
neutron-lib appeared. This is because tox installs neutron and its
requirements without any constraints. To fix this both the upper
constraints and neutron requirements needs to be added to dependencies
of docs target.

Closes-Bug: #1856156
Change-Id: Iea61238f37fdf24c0264f96d104ee0b3b6aec8e2
'}]
commit_message:
Use constraints for docs tox target

In Stein the docs target started to fail when new release of
neutron-lib appeared. This is because tox installs neutron and its
requirements without any constraints. To fix this both the upper
constraints and neutron requirements needs to be added to dependencies
of docs target.

Closes-Bug: #1856156
Change-Id: Iea61238f37fdf24c0264f96d104ee0b3b6aec8e2
