revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-06 07:11:38.000000000', 'message': 'Provide the output to add a validation for role-specific params on services

In order to provide role-specific parameters for a service,
"<RoleName>Parameters" should be used to provide the actual
parameter to be applied to a specific role (in the parameter_defaults
of user's environment file). Parameters require special implementation
to support role-specific in a service. This workflow validates the
user provided role-specific parameters with the actual implementation
and provides the invalid ones. The actual role-specific parameters
on a template could be found using the 'tags' attribute of a
parameter in the heat template.

Change-Id: Ie0abc345cea4a69b19b2ea760a29a2cab61c1ceb
(cherry picked from commit 8586cc1542e894e52767507e1ec87f3d9ac95e03)
'}]
commit_message:
Provide the output to add a validation for role-specific params on services

In order to provide role-specific parameters for a service,
"<RoleName>Parameters" should be used to provide the actual
parameter to be applied to a specific role (in the parameter_defaults
of user's environment file). Parameters require special implementation
to support role-specific in a service. This workflow validates the
user provided role-specific parameters with the actual implementation
and provides the invalid ones. The actual role-specific parameters
on a template could be found using the 'tags' attribute of a
parameter in the heat template.

Change-Id: Ie0abc345cea4a69b19b2ea760a29a2cab61c1ceb
(cherry picked from commit 8586cc1542e894e52767507e1ec87f3d9ac95e03)

As Moshe is pointing here, we should not backport a config option (and this will also impacts on deployment tools like TripleO).

Because the patch was cherry-picked up to Pike, IMO we can do two things:

- From Pike to Stein: add a tunnel port is not a frequent operation. We can handle this by adding a try/catch context there. If the add operation [1] fails, you can remove the parameter and try again.

- From Train: we have "baremetal_smartnic" (as Slawek suggested). This is enough to know that the agent OVS is of this type. We can use it to add or not this parameter.

commit_message:
Adds --all-cells to the archive command

Adds --all-cells to the archive command based on an empty_table
boolean flag. If true, it will run in archive command on all
configured cells.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/697012

Change-Id: Iaa47181318eb8b9251d47fd381784791f4967a4e
(cherry picked from commit bb08feae87642519524f2fa233e88cb65ee7bae8)
(cherry picked from commit ed807540ec79539311ae8450ac5558e441e9ee5f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 22:17:40.000000000', 'message': "bmc: assume powering-on state is ACTIVE

Inside newer deployments of OpenStack, it's possible that powering
on takes quite sometime especially with a large amount of ports
attached to the VM.  This is because Nova has to unplug and plug
all of the ports which can take a period of time.

During the period of time that Nova is starting the instance up,
the state of the VM is 'powering-on' and eventually it becomes
ACTIVE.  However, the IPMI status value presented is still offline
which is inaccurate.

In order to model this more towards a real bare metal environment,
we now maintain that 'powering-up' means the instance is active
which will let tools be able to move on with other steps like
PXE boot which was going to take sometime anyways.

If the booting fails, the instance will likely timeout and fail to
provision anyways, so we don't really lose much and on the next
refresh we'll figure out that state is SHUTOFF with no task state.

Change-Id: Ifa4d0152ec3086ef2e2b65e03a4499798964b78e
"}]
commit_message:
bmc: assume powering-on state is ACTIVE

Inside newer deployments of OpenStack, it's possible that powering
on takes quite sometime especially with a large amount of ports
attached to the VM.  This is because Nova has to unplug and plug
all of the ports which can take a period of time.

During the period of time that Nova is starting the instance up,
the state of the VM is 'powering-on' and eventually it becomes
ACTIVE.  However, the IPMI status value presented is still offline
which is inaccurate.

In order to model this more towards a real bare metal environment,
we now maintain that 'powering-up' means the instance is active
which will let tools be able to move on with other steps like
PXE boot which was going to take sometime anyways.

If the booting fails, the instance will likely timeout and fail to
provision anyways, so we don't really lose much and on the next
refresh we'll figure out that state is SHUTOFF with no task state.

Change-Id: Ifa4d0152ec3086ef2e2b65e03a4499798964b78e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-14 10:37:10.000000000', 'message': 'Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7. As we are dropping py2 support in
Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.
There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this is still used in project's CI.

Change-Id: I77a57228d2e66558fc3a10f4a2d5adede9e87ffe
'}]
commit_message:
Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7. As we are dropping py2 support in
Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.
There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this is still used in project's CI.

Change-Id: I77a57228d2e66558fc3a10f4a2d5adede9e87ffe

commit_message:
kolla/overrides: add missing healthcheck for ironic-neutron-agent

Not sure how we missed it but ironic-neutron-agent image was missing
its healthcheck script.

Change-Id: I6eca0eaec3f251414df7e92386f9c6978a212a81

commit_message:
Make opensuse jobs non-voting

The opensuse rocky jobs appear to be consistently failing, this
change makes them non-voting for now while the underlying issue
gets fixed.

Change-Id: I857114e68eeb9448ce1edbb44ac64ca1dae62466

commit_message:
Add prometheus-adapter

This will install the prometheus-adapter stable
helm chart. Requires monitoring_enabled=true.

The chart version can be configured using
prometheus_adapter_chart_tag and an option is
available to overwrite the default configuration
rules for a user defined ConfigMap referenced
by using prometheus_adapter_configmap label.

story: 2006765
task: 37278

Change-Id: I5b86f4455f88c8dbeac6e56942e1ca55f1d1726c
Signed-off-by: Diogo Guerra <diogo.filipe.tomas.guerra@cern.ch>

commit_message:
Make sure we always populate flavor_id

Starting with nova api microversion 2.47, the
server_get function no longer returns a flavor id.

Change-Id: I108b1917e12a676a6265c3e223b4f0b889833100

commit_message:
Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7. As we are dropping py2 support in
Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.
There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this is still used in project's CI.

Change-Id: I6a4ce001d6cbb4455386285c0d0a43be592e57d7

subject: Pad an extra 1GiB onto tempest flavor root disk
messages:
[{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-24 14:47:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-10-24 20:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-24 21:04:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hmm, this makes test_image_defined_boot_from_volume fail because we're using a 2gb disk but a 1gb volume. Likely means tempest's volume_size config option needs updating to match that size."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-24 21:05:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-24 21:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-24 21:31:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Hmm, this makes test_image_defined_boot_from_volume fail because we're using a 2gb disk but a 1gb volume. Likely means tempest's volume_size config option needs updating to match that size.

Yeah the default volume_size in tempest.conf is 1:

https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/52d7083f76c3b48650a7e6cda5fdad03332b51ed/tempest/config.py#L875

and we're hitting this during boot from volume in the compute API:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1bfa4626d13d0a73e63745cc4a864ae86d490daf/nova/utils.py#L761

And the flavor has root_gb=2 and the image has min_disk=0:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/290328c3f6ae455dbb410b421735efc8/log/controller/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#24340

So it blows up saying the volume is too small.

The root disk size in the flavor is an integer so we can't go like 1.5 there. We'd have to configure tempest's volume_size to be at least the larger of the two flavors used in tempest (which devstack should probably be setting that anyway), but I'm not sure if we'll start having issues creating 2gb volumes in test runs now - if anything it could make runs slightly slower, but maybe not noticeably so. I know we also used to run into issues with how much space was carved out on the host for volumes, but that defaults to 24GB in the gate now (VOLUME_BACKING_FILE_SIZE variable) so it shouldn't be a problem (would we have more than 12 volumes at the same time in a tempest run? probably not)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-24 21:46:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-24 21:51:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(1 comment)

Let's see if this does anything."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-25 13:49:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck run it again'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-28 16:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck job timeout'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-29 18:44:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck run it again'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-07 18:58:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-11 18:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-24 14:47:39.000000000', 'message': 'Pad an extra 1GiB onto tempest flavor root disk

Change I537c299b0cd400982189f35b31df74755422737e in Stein
changed the tempest flavor root disks from 0 to the size
of the image rounded up to the nearest GiB, which for the
small Cirros image we use in the gate is just 1.

Since then, we have seen intermittent ssh issues where the
guest console log shows:

  sh: write error: No space left on device
  ...
  GROWROOT: NOCHANGE: partition 1 is size 2078687. it cannot be grown

This change simply pads an extra 1GiB of space onto the root
disk for the tempest flavors to avoid running out of space in
the guest.

Change-Id: If19b2bc3523a046162f378cbf1bccf993971b55d
Related-Bug: #1808010
'}, {'created': '2019-10-24 21:46:30.000000000', 'message': "Pad an extra 1GiB onto tempest flavor root disk

Change I537c299b0cd400982189f35b31df74755422737e in Stein
changed the tempest flavor root disks from 0 to the size
of the image rounded up to the nearest GiB, which for the
small Cirros image we use in the gate is just 1.

Since then, we have seen intermittent ssh issues where the
guest console log shows:

  sh: write error: No space left on device
  ...
  GROWROOT: NOCHANGE: partition 1 is size 2078687. it cannot be grown

This change pads an extra 1GiB of space onto the root disk for
the tempest flavors to avoid running out of space in the guest.

Note that as a result, with the default cirros image we'll have
tempest flavors with a root disk of 2GiB and tempest defaults
volumes it creates to 1GiB, which will fail boot from volume
scenarios so we have to configure tempest's volume_size to be
the max of the root disk of the two flavors used in tempest runs.
Note that we probably should have been doing this anyway, we just
got lucky with the cirros image being rounded up to 1GiB and the
default volume size in tempest being 1GiB.

Change-Id: If19b2bc3523a046162f378cbf1bccf993971b55d
Related-Bug: #1808010
"}]
commit_message:
Pad an extra 1GiB onto tempest flavor root disk

Change I537c299b0cd400982189f35b31df74755422737e in Stein
changed the tempest flavor root disks from 0 to the size
of the image rounded up to the nearest GiB, which for the
small Cirros image we use in the gate is just 1.

Since then, we have seen intermittent ssh issues where the
guest console log shows:

  sh: write error: No space left on device
  ...
  GROWROOT: NOCHANGE: partition 1 is size 2078687. it cannot be grown

This change pads an extra 1GiB of space onto the root disk for
the tempest flavors to avoid running out of space in the guest.

Note that as a result, with the default cirros image we'll have
tempest flavors with a root disk of 2GiB and tempest defaults
volumes it creates to 1GiB, which will fail boot from volume
scenarios so we have to configure tempest's volume_size to be
the max of the root disk of the two flavors used in tempest runs.
Note that we probably should have been doing this anyway, we just
got lucky with the cirros image being rounded up to 1GiB and the
default volume size in tempest being 1GiB.

Change-Id: If19b2bc3523a046162f378cbf1bccf993971b55d
Related-Bug: #1808010

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-05 16:29:29.000000000', 'message': 'Use RequestSpec.requested_destination when rebuilding with new image

When rebuilding with a new image we modify the RequestSpec and set
force_hosts and force_nodes to restrict the scheduler to the current
host/node the instance is on, but this means there had to be a special
hack in the scheduler code to check for the special "_nova_check_type"
scheduler hint. This is because force_hosts/force_nodes means bypass
the filters, but in this case for rebuild with a new image we want
to run a subset of the filters for the new image to make sure it works
with the current host.

We could avoid that hack in the scheduler if we just used the
requested_destination field which means, "I want a given host/node
but still run the filters for me." Another benefit is that the
requested_destination field is not persisted, unlike the force_hosts
and force_nodes fields, which could get accidentally persisted if
the RequestSpec changes are saved later.

This change simply changes the rebuild flow to use the
requested_destination field rather than force_hosts/force_nodes.
The existing functional tests in ServerRebuildTestCase validate
this works.

A TODO is left in the scheduler code to remove the hack in the U
release because technically the API and scheduler service could be
running at different versions during an upgrade (but most likely
wouldn't be - I'm just paranoid).

Change-Id: Ia12e9e1b4aa494ffcad4fe2c94f8283bed657639
Partial-Bug: #1823369
'}, {'created': '2019-04-05 19:56:57.000000000', 'message': 'Use RequestSpec.requested_destination when rebuilding with new image

commit_message:
WIP: Use RequestSpec.requested_destination when rebuilding with new image

When rebuilding with a new image we modify the RequestSpec and set
force_hosts and force_nodes to restrict the scheduler to the current
host/node the instance is on, but this means there had to be a special
hack in the scheduler code to check for the special "_nova_check_type"
scheduler hint. This is because force_hosts/force_nodes means bypass
the filters, but in this case for rebuild with a new image we want
to run a subset of the filters for the new image to make sure it works
with the current host.

We could avoid that hack in the scheduler if we just used the
requested_destination field which means, "I want a given host/node
but still run the filters for me." Another benefit is that the
requested_destination field is not persisted, unlike the force_hosts
and force_nodes fields, which could get accidentally persisted if
the RequestSpec changes are saved later.

This change simply changes the rebuild flow to use the
requested_destination field rather than force_hosts/force_nodes.
The existing functional tests in ServerRebuildTestCase validate
this works.

A TODO is left in the scheduler code to remove the hack in the U
release because technically the API and scheduler service could be
running at different versions during an upgrade (but most likely
wouldn't be - I'm just paranoid).

Change-Id: Ia12e9e1b4aa494ffcad4fe2c94f8283bed657639

commit_message:
Exit 1 if a container fails and return the error

When a container's volumes failed validation, paunch still exited 0.
This caused the deployment to continue running even though not all
containers had been started.

This patch changes the rc to 1 when a container's volumes fail
validation and the container can't be started. The error message is also
returned in stderr so that it's available to the paunch ansible module
and will be seen in the deployment output.

Depends-On: I1f062b8b9f936e6fbf2febf64244e91b59b8ba1b
Change-Id: I67860a79572c0ff4dcaca9ec9597c41f56792fca
Closes-Bug: #1855444

commit_message:
Stop using six library

Since we've dropped support for Python 2.7, it's time to look at
the bright future that Python 3.x will bring and stop forcing
compatibility with older versions.
This patch removes the six library from requirements, not
looking back.

Change-Id: I4bf885bc7d1ccdf46dde3e0b10a8dbec304aaf9b

commit_message:
Ensure hostname resolved by kolla configured /etc/hosts file

Remove the existing host entries which conflict with kolla inventory
to ensure that the hostname resolution correct.

Change-Id: Ieb2c27b835f0638140ef7bf26eb00df79fa0a0e0
Closes-Bug: #1853578

commit_message:
l3 agent on network_hosts do dvr_snat, anywhere else dvr

With the change in queens of moving the neutron agents from
containers onto the network_hosts, if those hosts happen to
also be your nova_computes, VM's without a floating ip would
lose north/south network.

Checking for physical_host_group could make this patch work for
neutron_agents_containers on pike aswell, if we want to
backport it that far.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693809/1
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698009/1
Change-Id: I6bb24a8719b3902d6f510c70705cdb63076a1a08
Signed-off-by: Erik Berg <openstack@slipsprogrammor.no>
(cherry picked from commit edf0a25ca2e78658f06a2394a4ded60b49232bca)

commit_message:
Add $PROJECT: to the email subject in vmt guide

oss-security requires the affected project in the subject line of
disclosures on their mailing list.

This change adds "$PROJECT:" to the email subject template, as this
is required by oss-security and would be useful to the openstack
mailing lists as well.

Change-Id: I3bbd03079b0713d99e112cbc95c481bea49556ba

commit_message:
Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7. As we are dropping py2 support in
Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.
There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this is still used in project's CI.

Change-Id: Ie0faac1119c6d2bfea221ba60e26e67b6205909e

commit_message:
Remove zuul tenant ansible version pin

Zuul doesn't need to pin to ansible 2.8 anymore as this is now the
default in zuul itself.

Change-Id: I3d8ceff8a04ea1df58def7528739e488ae27bf92

commit_message:
Revert "Set default-ansible-version to 2.7 for all tenant (minus zuul)"

This reverts commit dff7fccc130a7c64d422b402d85d1f8669640a39.

We believe we've fixed the roles to work with ansible 2.8 and wish to
undo this pin now.

Change-Id: Ib6ffae651891bc85aa3a946f60085c5f5805c977

commit_message:
Enable image import plugins & image output format

Adding GlanceImageImportPlugins & GlanceImageConversionOutputFormat
to enable glance image conversion.

Since, glance-image-import.conf has been newly added while adding
plugin framework in glance, passing the conf file to puppet_tags
in docker service.

Depends-on: I098aa0cabf2518b8861d5b58b885d9bdef54a7f6
Change-Id: I81b788e38eecb3e0be88b140df3ae1ebb70cb191
Closes-Bug: #1807366

[{'created': '2019-12-11 07:26:21.000000000', 'message': 'Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7 and failing continuously. As we
are dropping py2 support in Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.

There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this is still used in project's CI.

Change-Id: I3e62c9ebc3e8673603b26acb9bacc543670bdf99
'}]
commit_message:
Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7 and failing continuously. As we
are dropping py2 support in Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.

There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this is still used in project's CI.

Change-Id: I3e62c9ebc3e8673603b26acb9bacc543670bdf99

[{'created': '2019-06-10 18:24:05.000000000', 'message': 'linuxscsi: Stop waiting for multipath devices during extend_volume

Previously linuxscsi.extend_volume would always attempt to wait for
multipath devices to appear regardless of multipath actually being used

This change corrects this by passing down the existing use_multipath

Change-Id: I29d65ae036957f3a63cba93dd330b14e3361a1b9

multipath devices to appear regardless of multipath actually being used
by the connector.

This change corrects this by passing down the existing use_multipath
attribute from the iSCSI and FC connectors into linuxscsi.extend_volume.
The same attribute is introduced to the NVMe connector to also allow it
to skip this search for multipath devices.

Change-Id: I29d65ae036957f3a63cba93dd330b14e3361a1b9
Closes-bug: #1832247
'}]
commit_message:
linuxscsi: Stop waiting for multipath devices during extend_volume

Previously linuxscsi.extend_volume would always attempt to wait for
multipath devices to appear regardless of multipath actually being used
by the connector.

This change corrects this by passing down the existing use_multipath
attribute from the iSCSI and FC connectors into linuxscsi.extend_volume.
The same attribute is introduced to the NVMe connector to also allow it
to skip this search for multipath devices.

Change-Id: I29d65ae036957f3a63cba93dd330b14e3361a1b9
Closes-bug: #1832247

commit_message:
Fix update API when barbican secret is missing

API update calls were blocked if the load balancer had a TLS
terminated listener that the secret has been removed from barbican.
This patch corrects this problem allowing users to update the
certificate reference.

Change-Id: I96908e6cbdb523f95298aff463a749d15e98e1ad
Story: 2006676
Task: 37322

subject: WIP: Migrate tests

[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-11 13:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-12-11 14:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Some feedbacks from my side.

Related to the flake8 issue
===========================

I can run tests without issue for https://review.opendev.org/#/c/651566/

Then tests start to fails during https://review.opendev.org/#/c/651565/

And continue to fail for this review.

By running `tox -e py37` I get the following error:
```
=========================
Failures during discovery
=========================
--- import errors ---
Failed to import test module: hacking.tests.test_doctest
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.7/unittest/loader.py", line 436, in _find_test_path
    module = self._get_module_from_name(name)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.7/unittest/loader.py", line 377, in _get_module_from_name
    __import__(name)
  File "/home/hberaud/dev/openstack/hacking/hacking/tests/test_doctest.py", line 19, in <module>
    from flake8.api import legacy as engine
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'flake8.api'
```

zuul side
=========

A lot of failures exist appear on
```
019-12-11 13:21:06.834929 | ubuntu-bionic |     b'Traceback (most recent call last):'
2019-12-11 13:21:06.835048 | ubuntu-bionic |     b'  File "/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/hacking/hacking/tests/test_doctest.py", line 48, in test_pycodestyle'
2019-12-11 13:21:06.835122 | ubuntu-bionic |     b'    report = pycodestyle.BaseReport(self.options)'
2019-12-11 13:21:06.835245 | ubuntu-bionic |     b'  File "/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/hacking/.tox/py37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pycodestyle.py", line 2027, in __init__'
2019-12-11 13:21:06.835311 | ubuntu-bionic |     b'    self._benchmark_keys = options.benchmark_keys'
2019-12-11 13:21:06.835380 | ubuntu-bionic |     b"AttributeError: 'Values' object has no attribute 'benchmark_keys'"
2019-12-11 13:21:06.835396 | ubuntu-bionic |     b''
2019-12-11 13:21:06.835580 | ubuntu-bionic | {0} hacking.tests.test_doctest.HackingTestCase.test_pycodestyle(H106-no_vim_headers-line-3) [0.000246s] ... FAILED
```

c.f https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_1df/651565/2/check/openstack-tox-py37/1df8aeb/job-output.txt

it can be worth to check recent changes and issues on https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/

Side things
===========

I think we need to blacklist sphinx 2.1.0 in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/651566/2/doc/requirements.txt

```
sphinx!=1.6.6,!=1.6.7,!=2.1.0,>=1.6.2;python_version>='3.4'  # BSD
```

c.f => https://review.opendev.org/#/c/687800/ and https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/6440'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-12-11 14:46:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Fixed this in [1] at last. Only took a few months :/

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-11 13:10:13.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Migrate tests

This isn't working and I can't for the life of me figure out why. It
works if I run things manually, like so:

  env -i .tox/py27/bin/python2.7 -mflake8 --isolated --select=$CODE --ignore=F $FILE

where $CODE and $FILE are in the output printed by the test.

flake8 also seems to be doing something funny with stdout and I'm not
able to capture things properly. WTF?

Change-Id: Iaa7528030c2feba493a08e713870ac3cd742802e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Migrate tests

This isn't working and I can't for the life of me figure out why. It
works if I run things manually, like so:

  env -i .tox/py27/bin/python2.7 -mflake8 --isolated --select=$CODE --ignore=F $FILE

where $CODE and $FILE are in the output printed by the test.

flake8 also seems to be doing something funny with stdout and I'm not
able to capture things properly. WTF?

Change-Id: Iaa7528030c2feba493a08e713870ac3cd742802e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 21:44:10.000000000', 'message': 'Update openstack-python-jobs-neutron templates

As we are dropping python 2 support in neutron effort tracked at:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-train-zuulv3-py27drop

We need to update this template used in projects depending on neutron to
not test anymore on python2, but on targeted python 3 versions for
current master branch

Change-Id: Ied999978ea2048626d5b3c2f82914b5bc64b9cd5
'}]
commit_message:
Update openstack-python-jobs-neutron templates

As we are dropping python 2 support in neutron effort tracked at:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-train-zuulv3-py27drop

We need to update this template used in projects depending on neutron to
not test anymore on python2, but on targeted python 3 versions for
current master branch

Change-Id: Ied999978ea2048626d5b3c2f82914b5bc64b9cd5

commit_message:
skydive: mark as unbuildable on !x86

Ie586b0f249e545877ab1dd156d08e1863cd479ba removed use of rpm packages so
it is time to disable building for non-x86 platforms.

Upstream provides own container images for several architectures.

Change-Id: I4778db57dae0953f5c7116105466c2830592b514

'}, {'created': '2018-12-10 09:28:48.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Reject migration requests when source is down

Attempts to migrate an instance from a host where the compute service is
down or unresponsive cannot obviously be completed until the service is
back online. As such we should reject these requests in a meaningful way
to the caller, returning a HTTPConflict 409 to indicate an issue with
the underlying state of the resources and environment.

Without this the instance task_state is updated to resize_prep by the
compute layer. This can in turn cause an UnexpectedTaskStateError error
to be thrown moving the instance into an ERROR state if the source
compute service restarts as it expects a task_state of None.

Closes-Bug: #1807434
Change-Id: I52e8db0a44382be74b44777106633a0246470b9c

commit_message:
compute: Reject resize requests when the source host is down

Attempts to resize or migrate an instance from a host where the compute
service is down or unresponsive cannot obviously be completed until the
service is back online. As such we should reject these requests in a
meaningful way to the caller, returning a HTTPConflict 409 to indicate
an issue with the underlying state of the resources and environment.

Without this the instance task_state is updated to resize_prep by the
compute layer. This can in turn cause an UnexpectedTaskStateError error
to be thrown moving the instance into an ERROR state if the source
compute service restarts as it expects a task_state of None.

Closes-Bug: #1807434
Change-Id: I52e8db0a44382be74b44777106633a0246470b9c

Example volume wait: https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/scenario/test_stamp_pattern.py#L58'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2019-02-07 09:21:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I am ok with moving the wait method into the helper function, however I would like to try to avoid assumption about bus details in temepst as much as possible.

Looks like the test in barbican previously ssh-ed the machine, which is also a MUST to do before attachment, linux can miss a hotplug even at early boot (The workaround is full pci rescan, but if you ssh machine before adding new device the hotplug subsystem is very likely fully alive before you can do an ssh and nothing else has to be done)'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-11-08 12:04:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-12-11 16:25:34.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Change-Id: I5c239354629e99f7ab571ea03a2c19d2a3e3b328
'}, {'created': '2019-01-21 14:56:09.000000000', 'message': 'Add SCSI rescan and lsblk output

Change-Id: I5c239354629e99f7ab571ea03a2c19d2a3e3b328
'}, {'created': '2019-01-31 11:40:24.000000000', 'message': 'Add SCSI rescan and lsblk debug output on failure

This change adds a simple SCSI rescan call helping to ensure the
attached device is seen within the guest OS ahead of a filesystem being
created and mounted.

Additionally `lsblk` output is now displayed on failures allowing easier
debugging over the simple directory listing previously provided.

commit_message:
Add SCSI rescan and lsblk debug output on failure

This change adds a simple SCSI rescan call helping to ensure the
attached device is seen within the guest OS ahead of a filesystem being
created and mounted.

Additionally `lsblk` output is now displayed on failures allowing easier
debugging over the simple directory listing previously provided.

Closes-Bug: #1811729
Change-Id: I5c239354629e99f7ab571ea03a2c19d2a3e3b328

commit_message:
WIP/DNM objects: Remove get_by_volume_id from BlockDeviceMapping

I06cdeef38aeb3f3e65dfc0ced8a75960b5d57f49 deprecated this method and by
switching the final caller in the compute API to
get_by_volume_and_instance we can now remove it from BlockDeviceMapping.

This is very naive WIP/DNM change as I don't have all of the required
context around bumping major o.vo objects such as this at the moment.

Change-Id: I7005b18f6e8b53d53a135f2cd59df366c575de4e

commit_message:
Don't use nodepool mirror

Fedora 27 images have been removed from the nodepool mirrors, see:

http://mirror.ord.rax.opendev.org/fedora/atomic/stable/

This was causing CI to fail, see:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/214b385dba404126adb5653b373d0260/log/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#27528

We now use the official fedora mirrors to download the VM images.

Change-Id: I3e5867675776ed3a07e62e87a5a68364d15d82a7

commit_message:
Use the version of neutron-common to determine the OpenStack version

There are transient situations where the config option openstack-origin will
hold the target OpenStack version, so it's not safe to be used to determine
what packages should be installed in the unit, an accurate method is to use
the version of the neutron-common package.

Change-Id: I88693be390f66ba94626e52b949b5573532ea5d7
Closes-Bug: #1854538

commit_message:
Remove undercloud's Operating System upgrade from workflow.

It was only from Rocky to Stein when the Openstack
upgrade implied an upgrade of the operating system.
For this reason, we are getting rid of this step
from Train onwards. However, we are leaving the
playbook which drives the Undercloud OS upgrade as
it might be useful for the FFWD procedure.

Change-Id: I2ef2d349a0b1a08c6b5ea357b9903e17c5dead3e

commit_message:
Fix pip install for run-local-test

This currently fails with:
ERROR: Double requirement given:
mock (from -r molecule-requirements.txt (line 10))
(already in mock>=2.0.0 (from -r test-requirements.txt (line 3)), name='mock')

The tox linters job uses the same pip requirements files but doesn't hit this
because it also passes the openstack upper constraints files, so do the same in
run-local-test.

Change-Id: I12602801147b99a4c17a02cfd43239897ee049f3

commit_message:
Make cert and ca cert ttl configurable

Currently the default ttl for a cert is not configurable
and defaults to one month. This patch makes the ttl
configurable and updates the default for new and
re-generated certs to 1 year and 10 years for the CA
cert.

Closes-Bug: #1841138

Change-Id: Iaa6709c74d64c4191b44b92d4cfb3a3dbbb3fdc8
(cherry picked from commit 5f233696a4afcc8cdf1f131892d99690f53bc61f)

commit_message:
Update for f29

In Fedora 29 dstat was merged with pcp-system-tools (see
https://pagure.io/fesco/issue/1956)

Work around a iscsi bug with external packages until we can get the
package fixed.

Obsolete F27

Change-Id: I2f16658c5a3e22cac70912a0f3ad65cdd7071a1e

subject: Cap sphinx for py2 to match global reqs
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-11 13:29:37.000000000', 'message': 'Cap sphinx for py2 to match global reqs

Sphinx had to be capped for py2 due to dropping support. We now need to
make sure the local entries match what is in global requirements.

Change-Id: I72144773da1a10cc515d5556e7e5047b8642f243
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Cap sphinx for py2 to match global reqs

Sphinx had to be capped for py2 due to dropping support. We now need to
make sure the local entries match what is in global requirements.

Change-Id: I72144773da1a10cc515d5556e7e5047b8642f243
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-11 08:54:46.000000000', 'message': "Include dnsmasq-utils package on all Ubuntu versions

This package provides dhcp_release tool but in files/debs/neutron-common
it was listed to be installed only on Ubuntu Precise.
The same file is also in Nova's packages but there is no restriction to
Ubuntu Precise only there.
So on all Neutron jobs it was fine but on Ironic's job where Nova
wasn't enabled, this package was not installed and caused problems
in Neutron DHCP agent.

Change-Id: Idd0711cfe6d43f21754a2f0c230cd094ea33cb27
Closes-Bug: #1855910
"}]
commit_message:
Include dnsmasq-utils package on all Ubuntu versions

This package provides dhcp_release tool but in files/debs/neutron-common
it was listed to be installed only on Ubuntu Precise.
The same file is also in Nova's packages but there is no restriction to
Ubuntu Precise only there.
So on all Neutron jobs it was fine but on Ironic's job where Nova
wasn't enabled, this package was not installed and caused problems
in Neutron DHCP agent.

Change-Id: Idd0711cfe6d43f21754a2f0c230cd094ea33cb27
Closes-Bug: #1855910

commit_message:
Ignore pep8 W503/W504

W503 has been reversed in current pep8, so we
shouldn't start enforcing this here.

W504 takes the opposite stance of W503.

Neither of these seem worth enforcing in our
code for now, just punt on a strict rule for
this and aim for readable code.

Change-Id: Id38b2629ea22792bbc7b4dce77fa9e7039be140f

commit_message:
Ensure not found exception is ignored when LB is not present

When using ovn-octavia driver a load balancer can be deleted
fast enought to cause a NotFoundException when trying to retrieve
it, which is different than the current exception being handled.
This commit ensures the additional exception is handled.

Change-Id: I11edd23303a017b281ef3a9a4ff28ee8baeb08cd
Closes-bug: 1853498
(cherry picked from commit 24499178317d41e699593feac5e3e63e368a5b0d)

commit_message:
Add containerized_undercloud_upgrade variable.

When upgrading from Queens to Rocky, we are jumping from a
non-containerized undercloud into a containerized one.
However, this scenario hasn't been considered yet. When
submitting [0] we add the logic to upgrade always to a
containerized undercloud, we need to have a variable that
allows us differentiate between the type (containerized or
non-containrized) of undercloud we deploy and upgrade to.

[0] - Ibcdfd71b9280615aedc4d59ef0c566c475f15d0b

Related-Bug: #1855856

Change-Id: I30b4789adcf348c636d3679523075b22f8956ff1

commit_message:
Ensure rabbitmq deployment container is restarted at every update

In [1] we lost the ability to restart deployment containers such as
rabbitmq_bootstrap and rabbitmq_init_bundle every time a stack update
or minor update is run. A fix for it [2] was attempted but was only
partial so not working.

Make sure we reintroduce variable TRIPLEO_DEPLOY_IDENTIFIER in all
the rabbitmq deployment containers (HA and non-HA) to make sure they
get restarted as expected at every update.

[1] I894f339cdf03bc2a93c588f826f738b0b851a3ad
[2] I139c2c276c8f532d37fceafe06f9547048e76906

Change-Id: I131a905b62cd990deee1ae6aa81ab2560c98a7c8
Closes-Bug: #1855732

commit_message:
overcloud/service_names: merge service_names & enabled_services

When building ServiceNames, make sure we merge the YAQL results of both
enabled_services & service_names queries; so we don't end up with
duplicates.

Change-Id: I1f062b8b9f936e6fbf2febf64244e91b59b8ba1b
Related-Bug: #1855138
(cherry picked from commit f5d8df16d9e7d5008ec726cb33bec9c588fbf7fe)

commit_message:
Switch to generic package module

This makes platform independence easier. There are some cases where we
still use the yum module, where we use yum-specific module parameters.

Also switch use of the state 'installed' to 'present', which is
supported by all the package modules, whereas installed is supported by
the yum module only.

Change-Id: Id1cf845adc7aa6565a7a570569c9a81a478560f0

"}, {'created': '2019-12-03 13:58:58.000000000', 'message': 'Install ndisc6 package in element script

The ndisc6 package is not yet available in EPEL 8.
See: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1779134

Until the package is available set the pkg-map to "" for
the ndisc6 package when distro is redhat and install the
package using || true in the element script instead so
that CentOS 8 build's do not fail because of the missing
package.

Once the package is in EPEL 8 this change can be reverted.

Related-Bug: #1754219
Change-Id: Icd4bad8852ce5ba40fb0e7b0d335191efbe88c67
'}]
commit_message:
Install ndisc6 package in element script

The ndisc6 package is not yet available in EPEL 8.
See: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1779134

Until the package is available set the pkg-map to "" for
the ndisc6 package when distro is redhat and install the
package using || true in the element script instead so
that CentOS 8 build's do not fail because of the missing
package.

Once the package is in EPEL 8 this change can be reverted.

Related-Bug: #1754219
Change-Id: Icd4bad8852ce5ba40fb0e7b0d335191efbe88c67

[{'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-05-17 01:22:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-05-17 01:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Thanks Ian  that looks great!'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-17 13:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is really nice, thanks!

In the current diagram the global lower constraint value should actually point to 1.1.0, because nova does not work with 1.0.1.

You use pyfoo-lib as a generic name for a dependency. I wonder if it would be better to use generic names for the services, too, for the same reason. "Service A" and "Service B" or something.

It would be useful to highlight that 2.0.1 is a newer release than we are testing with. We can do that in text. In fact, maybe most of the text should move to just regular text around the image? That would make it easier to read, change, and expand.

In the global requirement box, maybe you could say pyfoo-lib!=1.1.2 and then we could explain the exclusion? Maybe that's cluttering this diagram up too much, though.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-17 13:50:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Loving it! +1 on Doug's suggestions"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-03-16 02:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This has been sitting for awhile. Looks like Doug had some good suggestions, but I would need to recheck to see the output at this point. If there are changes desired I am reluctant to do that.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-07-01 12:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Looking at this again it occurs to me that none of this can be translated, and since the text is in an image, a non-English reader would not be able to easily copy out text into some sort of translation tool either. I wonder if there is a different way we can display this without making the entire thing an image.

I do like the visual representation though, so I hope we can get something like this included at some point.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-07-22 08:53:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Looking at this again it occurs to me that none of this can be
 > translated, and since the text is in an image, a non-English reader
 > would not be able to easily copy out text into some sort of
 > translation tool either. I wonder if there is a different way we
 > can display this without making the entire thing an image.
 > 
 > I do like the visual representation though, so I hope we can get
 > something like this included at some point.

A few (poor) substitutes for images can be: a table, using something like ascii text to "draw" a flow chart (of sorts)...

We do want the barrier to entry to be open to all, but not everything can be translated regardless. A suggestion would be to include "subtitles" of sort underneath the image to explain what it is. That can be translated roughly and would work.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-28 10:07:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-13 11:21:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-14 10:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-14 10:14:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

New diagrams incorporating Doug's comments, to hopefully finally merge this."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-11-15 18:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-12-11 10:10:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-10 18:49:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix timezones in certificate revocation list dates

While generating certificate revocation list, dates were generated with
an incorrect TZ information. Depending on the TZ of host, some tests
failed because last update was in the future.

Using datetime.utcnow() for dates fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I2ff30c1a65e07b409aba211d1c60760355bfebbe
'}]
commit_message:
Fix timezones in certificate revocation list dates

While generating certificate revocation list, dates were generated with
an incorrect TZ information. Depending on the TZ of host, some tests
failed because last update was in the future.

Using datetime.utcnow() for dates fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I2ff30c1a65e07b409aba211d1c60760355bfebbe

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-22 14:59:09.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] [OVS] Handle added/removed ports in the same polling iteration

The OVS agent processes the port events in a polling loop. It could happen
(and more frecuently in a loaded OVS agent) that the "removed" and "added"
events can happen in the same polling iteration. Because of this, the same
port is detected as "removed" and "added".

When the virtual machine is restarted, the port event sequence is "removed"
and then "added". When both events are captured in the same iteration, the
port is already present in the bridge and the port is discharted from the
"removed" list.

Because the port was removed first and the added, the QoS policies do not
apply anymore (QoS and Queue registers, OF rules). If the QoS policy does
not change, the QoS agent driver will detect it and won't call the QoS
driver methods (based on the OVS agent QoS cache, storing port and QoS rules).
This will lead to an unconfigured port.

This patch solves this issue by detecting this doble event and registering it
as "removed_and_added". When the "added" port is handled, the QoS deletion
method is called first (if needed) to remove the unneded artifacts (OVS
registers, OF rules) and remove the QoS cache (port/QoS policy). Then the
QoS policy is applied again on the port.

NOTE: this is going to be quite difficult to be tested in a fullstack test.

Change-Id: I51eef168fa8c18a3e4cee57c9ff86046ea9203fd
Closes-Bug: #1845161

commit_message:
[OVS] Handle added/removed ports in the same polling iteration

The OVS agent processes the port events in a polling loop. It could
happen (and more frequently in a loaded OVS agent) that the "removed"
and "added" events can happen in the same polling iteration. Because
of this, the same port is detected as "removed" and "added".

When the virtual machine is restarted, the port event sequence is
"removed" and then "added". When both events are captured in the same
iteration, the port is already present in the bridge and the port is
discharted from the "removed" list.

Because the port was removed first and the added, the QoS policies do
not apply anymore (QoS and Queue registers, OF rules). If the QoS
policy does not change, the QoS agent driver will detect it and won't
call the QoS driver methods (based on the OVS agent QoS cache, storing
port and QoS rules). This will lead to an unconfigured port.

This patch solves this issue by detecting this double event and
registering it as "removed_and_added". When the "added" port is
handled, the QoS deletion method is called first (if needed) to remove
the unneded artifacts (OVS registers, OF rules) and remove the QoS
cache (port/QoS policy). Then the QoS policy is applied again on the
port.

NOTE: this is going to be quite difficult to be tested in a fullstack test.

Change-Id: I51eef168fa8c18a3e4cee57c9ff86046ea9203fd
Closes-Bug: #1845161

commit_message:
Accept oslopolicy-policy-generator path arguments

The Octavia policy enforcer object used by the oslopolicy-policy-generator
must pass the --config-file or --config-dir command line arguments to
oslo.config, otherwise those arguments are ignored.

Change-Id: Ic638c056715f8fcea3b095726964e7224c38eae2
Task: 37743
Story: 2006983
